live,” said Richter.&nbsp“Their slums, impoverishment, degradation and prostitution!&nbsp That’s where your foreign policy should lie.&nbspThey are the victims of your capitalist organisation which is just as powerful and cruel as the force of arms.”Morley and others politely begged to differ –&nbspso politely that Richter was invited back to Toynbee Hall for tea a few days later.William Bowman, a Toynbee Hall resident who was present at the tea, recalled how Richter, “who seemed hungry”, tucked into the cakes and was particularly fascinated by the buttered muffins, which he had never tried before.But he wouldn’t budge from his belief in violent revolution.“History has shown,” he told the Toynbee Hall residents between mouthfuls of cake and muffins, “that no great change has been brought about without the shedding of blood and revolution.”Eventually he declared: “I have enjoyed this talk, but now my time is up.&nbspI must go to visit my friends in Limehouse.”Richter&nbspshook hands with the assembled company and departed.&nbspOnly much later did the Toynbee Hall residents realise that they had in fact been having tea with the exiled Russian revolutionary Vladimir Lenin.In a gentler way, some of the stances taken by Toynbee Hall and its residents have been, if not revolutionary, then at least profoundly challenging to conventional wisdom.&nbspEven as the hall opened, the Barnetts were&nbspin the process of parting ways with the Charity Organisation Society (COS), which had started in 1869 as the Society for Organising Charitable Relief and Repressing Mendicity.Much emphasis was placed on repressing mendicity&nbsp– begging.&nbspRather as some now rail against a perceived “benefits culture”, the social reformer Octavia Hill, a driving force in the COS, firmly believed that indiscriminate alms-giving “degraded” the poor, making them happy to rely on charity and unable or unwilling to support themselves through hard work.In a possible echo of the current debates around fit-to-work benefits tests, it was believed that extensive scrutiny of applications for “relief” was needed to distinguish the virtuous but luckless worker from the “clever pauper”.“The main tone of action,” maintained Hill, “must be severe.&nbspThere is much of rebuke and repression needed, although a deep and silent undercurrent of pity may flow beneath.”In the eyes of the Fabian Beatrice Webb, the Barnetts “discovered that there was a deeper evil than unrestrained charity, namely unrestricted and unregulated capitalism and landlordism.”And so in 1888 the matchgirls of the East End found allies in Toynbee Hall when they went on strike, protesting against pitiful wages and factory conditions that included white phosphorous fumes destroying jawbones, giving&nbspmatch-makers “phossy-jaw”.In an early example of Toynbee Hall residents learning from their East End neighbours, a group of them made their own investigations, then helped shape public opinion with letters to The Times detailing the matchgirls’ “deplorable conditions” and below-subsistence wages.&nbspAfter its first warden Samuel Barnett died in 1913, it could be said that Toynbee Hall rose to other challenges.&nbspOn Sunday 4 October&nbsp1936 Oswald Mosley tried to march his uniformed blackshirts through the East End.&nbspJewish groups, trade unionists and leftwingers mobilised to block the fascists’ path with barricades and cries of “They shall not pass!”When the police tried to clear a route for the British Union of Fascists, the “Battle of Cable Street” began.&nbspThe fascists did not pass.&nbspDefeated by the dogged East Enders, police commissioner Sir Philip Game was forced to tell Mosley to march west, out of the area.A week later, however, in what became known as the Mile End Pogrom, about 200 fascists smashed up Jewish shops and houses in the Mile End Road, even throwing a young child and elderly Jewish man through a window.Toynbee Hall warden Jimmy Mallon was appalled.&nbspHe called a meeting at Toynbee Hall that led to the creation of a Council of Citizens of East London, which then issued a notice to be displayed in shops and workplaces.&nbsp“Citizens of East London,” the notice warned.&nbsp “Forces are at work to destroy the common sense and toleration and good humour on which we pride ourselves.&nbspWe must work against these forces.&nbspBoycott provocative demonstrations.&nbspMaintain calm and good temper.&nbspStand together for fair play.”Meanwhile, Jimmy Mallon joined a delegation that persuaded the government of the need for what became the Public Order Act 1936.It banned the wearing of uniforms for political purposes, as well as enhancing police powers to deal with marches.Profumo found redemption at Toynbee Hall, rising from dishwasher to chairman (Toynbee Hall Archives)Such achievements are, perhaps, one answer to the sour aside of East Ender and future Labour leader George Lansbury, who in 1928 wrote that Toynbee Hall was used as a stepping stone by ambitious young careerists who would eventually claim that: “The interests of the poor were best served by leaving east London to stew in its own juice while they became members of parliament, cabinet ministers, civil servants.”Had he lived long enough, Lansbury might have added that Toynbee Hall was also used by at least one ex-cabinet minister to forge a new, post-scandal career.It is often recalled that in 1963, after being caught lying to parliament about his affair with Christine Keeler, John Profumo began a new career washing dishes at Toynbee Hall, rising to become chairman in 1982 and “learning humility” in the process.&nbspBut it is often forgotten how much Profumo achieved at Toynbee Hall.&nbspHe raised funds, helped ease overcrowding through involvement in the Toynbee Housing Association, and backed potentially controversial schemes like the “Grendon outpost”, providing aftercare for former psychiatric-prison inmates.In what could have been another riposte to George Lansbury, William Beveridge freely acknowledged that his coming to Toynbee Hall, aged 24, in 1903 had been the stepping stone to other things.&nbspBut in the same breath, he said that none of his later achievements would have been possible without the “special knowledge … gained in Whitechapel”.During his two years at Toynbee Hall, Beveridge was able, he later recalled, “to learn about the main economic problem of those days, not from books, but by interviewing unemployed applicants for relief”.And Beveridge’s recommendations were implemented by the post-war government of fellow Toynbee alumnus Clement Attlee, who spent a year as the hall’s secretary in 1910.&nbspAttlee came to Toynbee Hall with prior experience of the East End, having been the manager of Stepney Boys’ Club and an assistant to Beatrice Webb.In his 1920 book Social Worker, the Oxford-educated former public schoolboy revealed some of the lessons the East End had taught him.I met a small boy in the street one day.Attlee (first left) at Toynbee Hall in 1910 (Courtesy of Anne, Countess Attlee)Echoing the Barnetts’&nbspgrowing distaste for the COS, while seemingly anticipating some of the thinking behind – and modern arguments about – the welfare state, Attlee inveighed against&nbsp“the suggestion that those in need of relief should be passed through a sort of sieve”“They will spend much time finding ways in which small wages may be made to go a long way, without considering whether those wages should not be raised, or recognising that the claim to a share in the better things of life which is expressed in the purchase of luxuries is a more hopeful thing than submission to low wages.”In the newly restored Toynbee Hall, Jim Minton expresses pride in the connection to men like Attlee and Beveridge. But he is careful to temper such pride with a recognition of the work still to be done.&nbspDespite 134 years of “progress”, despite the wealth represented by those gleaming City of London towers, the East End – still – contains two of the three worst-rated UK parliamentary constituencies for child poverty.&nbspAnd in 2015, the last time such official statistics were compiled, the east London boroughs of Tower Hamlets, Hackney and Newham were ranked the worst local authority areas in the country for income-deprivation among older people.Child food poverty ‘sparks return of Victorian scourges’Nearly half of all children in London and Birmingham ‘live in poverty’Government must tackle ‘slum’ conditions faced by private rentersMy forefather’s life in Manchester’s slumsTower Hamlets, Toynbee Hall’s local borough, has about 2,000 homeless families in temporary accommodation and in 2015 just over a quarter of its population was found to be living in income deprivation.“We are talking every day to people who have financial problems,” says&nbspMinton.&nbsp“There are still huge amounts of poverty in east London.“The learning process that Attlee and Beveridge and hundreds of other less famous people would have gone through at Toynbee Hall,” says Minton, “would have been about challenging, and saying: ‘This is unacceptable.&nbspWhy is this happening, and what can we do about it?’”“That,” he declares, “is very much the spirit we want to keep alive.”&nbsp‘Toynbee Hall: A Powerhouse for Social Change’ is open Monday-Friday and on the third weekend of every month at PoliticsTheresa May will seek approval from her cabinet soon after conference for further tweaks to her Brexit plans in a bid to secure a deal from the EU.The prime minister is set to reshape her customs proposals and also look at whether there is scope to make an offer to Brussels on the alignment of future regulation.The Independent&nbspalready reported earlier this week how government officials had been tasked to start looking at an “Chequers 2” position that might be sold to EU negotiators in a bid to seal a deal by November.Brexiteer Chris Grayling compares Brexit to aviation disasterCabinet ministers have also now confirmed their desire to ditch the word “Chequers” from future proposals, saying that it is now a damaged brand that needs to be cut loose.Allies of the prime minister are bracing themselves at Conservative conference in Birmingham for Boris Johnson to make a speech on Tuesday trashing the prime minister’s proposals and calling for them to be ditched altogether.One frontbencher said the coming changes to Ms May’s plans would aim to break the impasse in Brexit talks, adding: “She will get conference out of the way first, you can’t do anything here because it would be too isive.“But once we’re refocussed on the talks in Brussels then there will be moves to get the deal done by November.”The Independent&nbspunderstands the PM is in particular looking to make changes to her Chequers plan which would reshape her complex proposals for customs arrangements.As it stands they would see the EU and UK collecting tariffs on behalf of each other in order to ensure there is frictionless trade across the UK’s borders, but they have been branded unworkable in many European capitals.Officials have indicated that the new approach would prioritise frictionless trade and instead&nbspsee a customs approach proposed that is more aligned to the EU’s.We have to get the word Chequers out of the conversation It’s a damaged brand, difficult to get excited about and I don’t think it’s particularly helpfulThe prime minister is also considering if she can do anything to allay fears EU that Britain will refuse to adopt new environmental and social regulation taken on by Brussels, allowing it a competitive advantage after Brexit.But cabinet ministers who back her strategy are eager to ensure that it does not fall foul of the ill will in the party and wider country already provoked by the row over her Chequers proposals&nbspA cabinet minister said: “We will get a deal. BrexitClick to followIndy PoliticsA “significant” number of Tory MPs&nbspwould be prepared to back a second&nbspreferendum on Theresa May’s&nbspBrexit deal, a senior Conservative has said.Ex-attorney general Dominic Grieve said the prime minister was facing a “polite rebellion” of pro-EU Tories&nbspwho think a new vote is “indispensable” to avoiding a damaging no-deal Brexit.Mr Grieve became one of the first senior Tories to break cover over&nbspthe need for a new referendum earlier this year, telling The Independent it was the “only sensible way forward”.Allen backs fresh Brexit referendum saying there is ‘no alternative’He has been&nbspjoined by prominent backbenchers Anna Soubry, Justine Greening, Sarah Wollaston, Philip Lee&nbspand&nbspGuto Bebb – and South Cambridgeshire MP Heidi Allen, who declared the Chequers plan was “dead” on Saturday.The Independent has been campaigning for the public to have a say on any deal Ms May secures with Brussels, which has won the backing of more than 820,000 people.Mr Grieve’s intervention comes at the start of what promises to be a fraught party conference for the prime minister, as she seeks to sell her Brexit plan to her ided party.Labour members voted to keep&nbspthe option of a second referendum&nbsp– including the potential to remain in the EU&nbsp– on the table at their conference last week, which means there could be a&nbspparliamentary majority in favour of another vote, Mr&nbspGrieve&nbspsaid.New Brexit referendum is ‘sensible way forward’, says Dominic GrieveGrieve warns of ‘state of emergency’ if no Brexit deal by FebruaryFinal Say: Rod Stewart backs calls for second referendum on BrexitCorbyn indicates shift in Brexit stance towards final say voteWriting in the Sunday , the MP for Beaconsfield said: “I believe the time has come for a polite rebellion by pragmatic Conservatives.“Including myself, it is now clear that there is a significant group of Conservative MPs who think that a People’s Vote – a vote on the final form Brexit will take, is absolutely indispensable for the future wellbeing of our country.”Mr Grieve&nbspadded: “A no-deal Brexit is a proposal so damaging to our future that it cannot be accepted.“So the only possible response must be to return to the British electorate and ask them what they want. title: elephant news rhinos poachers born free
story: James Bond machine fighting wildlife crime (Image: MGM)Agile, stealthy and capable at flying a low speed, the new generation of autogyros &ndash known as Dragons &ndash will&nbspgive rangers a vital lift in tackling the desperate gangs killing 55 elephants every day.British-based charity Born Free has launched an appeal to give frontline wildlife protectors aerial&nbspadvantage in the war to stop the iconic creatures being driven towards extinction.It costs &pound50,000 to buy a Dragon GBT 1170 autogyro and train a pilot to fly over tracts of unforgiving African&nbsplandscape, gathering vital intelligence in minutes that would take weeks for ground patrols weeks to cover.With London hosting the Illegal Wildlife Trade summit next week, there is a growing global imperative to thwart&nbspthe estimated &pound15.5billion a year criminal enterprises pushing endangered wildlife progressively towards&nbspoblivion.                Crusade to rescue wildlife from extinction                SNOW IN AFRICA: Giraffes, elephants and antelopes covered in snow Protecting creatures&nbspin the bush and forests is&nbspbecoming increasingly fraught, with more&nbspthan 890&nbsprangers killed on duty over the last&nbspdecade.Born Free hopes to&nbspgive rangers vital air&nbspsuperiority in key wildlife zones across&nbspAfrica by deploying&nbspthe Dragon autogyros&nbspfitted with live-tracking technology, infra-red&nbspoptics and&nbspsecure videovoice&nbspcommunications to liaise with on-the-ground rangers.The Dragons can take&nbspoff in areas the size of&nbspa small garden, fly quietly and safely at low&nbspspeeds,&nbspand also carry an observer along with the pilot.Autogyros grabbed the public&rsquos&nbspattention&nbspmore than 50 years ago when Sean Connery&nbsptook to the skies in a&nbspheavily-armed one&nbspdubbed Little Nellie provided by MI6&nbspquartermaster Q for&nbspone of Bond&rsquos most daring&nbspsecret missions.Since then, special&nbspforces around the world&nbsphave used the light aircraft in covert operations while&nbspthey have also&nbspprovided a boon for law&nbspenforcers. Three years ago, a pilot&nbspachieved the&nbsphighest altitude for an autogyro, reaching&nbspmore than 26,000ft.Dragon GBT 1170 autogyro (Image: Born Free)Born Free is teaming up with Staffordshire-based Chimera Aviation to launch its first &ldquodragons of the sky in South Africa.The charity&rsquos chief executive Howard Jones explained: &ldquoSometimes the campaign against poaching and other&nbspillegal activity, has felt like a debilitating, endless battle. Rhino are systematically targeted by poachers for their&nbsphorns. Fewer than 29,000 remain, and between 2008 and 2017, more than 7,000 were killed by poachers in&nbspSouth Africa alone. And, as our Born Free &lsquoElephants in Crisis&rsquo campaign earlier this year highlighted, an&nbspaverage of 55 African elephants are killed by poachers every day for their tusks. That&rsquos about one every 25&nbspminutes.&ldquoDespite the fact that men and women around the world are putting their lives on the line to tackle the dreadful&nbspcrimes of illegal wildlife trade and poaching, it just isn&rsquot possible to deter and protect, all day, all night and every&nbspday. &nbsp                HEARTBREAKING video shows baby elephant WITHOUT his trunk55 elephants a day slaughtered for the ivory in Africa (Image: Born Free)&ldquoTo cover these vast and challenging areas, to then fight through thick vegetation in time to reach poachers, or&nbspto prevent their presence in the first place, has seemed almost impossible. Deploying the Dragon will transform&nbspour capability and help turn the current balance on its head. &nbspThis will allow our rangers to protect extensive&nbspareas safely, economically and efficiently, with much-enhanced surveillance capacity and flexibility, when&nbspcompared to other aircraft.The charity will launch the first Dragons at the Shamwari Private Game Reserve in South Africa, which is home&nbspto two of its big cat sanctuaries as well as providing a haven for wildlife across a 100 square miles of rough&nbspcountry, which is patrolled by some of the most advanced anti-poaching units. Garamba in the Democratic&nbspRepublic of Congo, &nbspwhich has witnessed horrific numbers of elephants being slaughtered in recent years, is&nbspalso in line for the aircraft.&nbsp&ldquoWe are hoping that with public backing we can prove this method of poaching reduction is effective, and roll&nbspout the Dragon initiative in 10 other key areas of Africa, including Kenya, Ethiopia and Zambia within the next&nbsp12 months, and provide training for all local pilots and rangers, added Mr Jones.For more details, see:&nbsphttps:www.bornfree.org.ukdragon

title: Dog news researchers intelligence smart
story: Dogs are not as smart as they would like us to think (Image: Getty)Our dedicated, doting companions have won a place in our hearts with their incredible devotion to duty.They herd livestock, guard our homes and sniff out trouble, besides delighting us with their wagging tails and friendly licks.Yet for the all their associations with humanity over the past 15,000 years and the remarkable selfless acts they perform, people who think dogs are exceptionally intelligent are barking up the wrong tree, say researchers.Academics from the University of Exeter and Canterbury Christ Church University have dispelled the myths of dogs having super brainpower by comparing their cognitive abilities with other creatures and have discovered many are just as smart.Pigs can smell humans as well as sniffer dogs (Image: Getty)Pigs can identify humans by their smell, cats can identify human voices and sheep and pigeons can recognise our faces.When it comes to navigating barriers, donkeys and horses are as adept as dogs, while goats, pigs, seals and sealions can follow when humans point.After studying more than 300 scientific papers on animal intelligence, researchers say they have found several cases of &ldquoover interpretation in favour of dogs&rsquo abilities.&nbsp&ldquoDuring our work it seemed to us that many studies in dog cognition research set out to &lsquoprove&rsquo how clever dogs are, said Professor Stephen Lea, of the University of Exeter.&nbsp&ldquoThey are often compared to chimpanzees and whenever dogs &lsquowin&rsquo, this gets added to their reputation as something exceptional.&ldquoYet in each and every case we found other valid comparison species that do at least as well as dogs do in those tasks.Dogs intelligence has been brought to book by new research (Image: Getty)At the heart of study was a review of animal sensory cognition, physical cognition, spatial cognition, social cognition and self-awareness, but after looking at domestic animals, social hunters and carnivorans, such as lions, bears or hyenas, the scientists conclude that dogs are not exceptional.Dr Britta Osthaus, of Canterbury Christ Church University, explained:&nbsp&ldquoWe are doing dogs no favour by expecting too much of them. Dogs are dogs, and we need to take their needs and true abilities into account when considering how we treat them.&nbspThe research, titled In what sense are dogs special? Canine cognition in comparative context,&nbspappears in the journal Learning &amp Behavior.

title: brexit news jacob rees mogg conservative party conference leave means leave
story: Jacob Rees-Mogg responded with trademark good humour (Image: )At a packed Leave Means Leave rally, an EU flag pyjama-wearing protester blasted out music from a portable sound system outside the event room.The music was by &ldquoEU Supergirl, a pro-EU campaigner and singer, and it was played at a volume which brought the event to a halt.But rather than be put off by the protest, Jacob Rees-Mogg responded with trademark good humour.As music blared in from outside, he quipped: &ldquoAnything they can do we can do louder!                Jacob-Rees Mogg responds to Boris Johnson Tory leadership claimsLeave Means Leave co-chair Richard Tice also helped to diffuse the situation.A video has emerged which shows Mr Tice speaking politely to the protestor, who he asked to turn the music off.Remarkably, the protester does so and even apologises before walking away.Political journalist and commentator Isabel Oakeshott said on Twitter: &ldquoThe Leave Means Leave fringe descends into farce as saboteurs attempt to drown out Jacob Rees Mogg with deafening Muzak.Mr Rees-Mogg received a standing ovation (Image: )                Brexit news: Juncker says EU will block UK plane landings in no deal                Brexit latest: What is May's concession on Northern Ireland?She later added added: &ldquoRemoaners fail to drown out Jacob Rees-Mogg who is now descanting on Aesop Fables.&ldquoIt&rsquos all become a bit surreal.Mr Rees-Mogg received a standing ovation after his speech at the fringe event.Other speakers included Wetherspoons chief Tim Martin.Leave Means Leave co-chair Richard Tice also helped to diffuse the situation (Image: )Mr Martin said: &ldquoEverything you buy from the EU you can buy from elsewhere in the world - the power lies with the consumer.There were cries of &ldquosack the woman! from hecklers at the event who want Mr Rees-Mogg to support a bid to oust Theresa May.The leading Brexiteer replied: &ldquoAbsolutely not.He claimed that changing the Conservatives leader would cause more problems than it solves and the party should back the Prime Minister.Mr Rees-Mogg is considered a possible successor to May.He said the Conservatives lack of a parliamentary majority meant it would be difficult for an alternative leader to push through an ambitious Brexit deal.

title: brexit latest news irish border hard border no deal brexit chancellor philip hammond
story: Philip Hammond warned no-deal would mean a hard border (Image: )The Chancellor said World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules meant London would have no choice but to reinstate checks if it left the EU without an agreement next March.Speaking at a fringe event at the Conservative Party conference in Birmingham, Mr Hammond said: &ldquoThe challenges around the Irish border are around the legal requirements we will have if we are not in a trade block within the European Union to operate the WTO compliant border, which does require checks at the border. That&rsquos what the WTO rules require.&ldquoWe are depending on the WTO to regulate our relations with the rest of the world, we will have to comply with the rest of WTO regulations or we will find we can&rsquot enforce our WTO rights against others.Mr Hammond&rsquos comments came as Theresa May appeared to signal a change of position on the Irish border issue.                Brexit news: May preparing to offer EU Irish border concession                Brexit latest: What is May's concession on Northern Ireland?A senior Government official said the Prime Minister intended to make a dramatic new Irish backstop offer to Brussels, which will soften her approach to allowing a number of regulatory goods checks demanded by the European Union&rsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier.The official said she was likely to accept the EU&rsquos desired new checks on goods moving between British mainland and Northern Ireland in order to unblock deadlocked negotiations.For her plan to work, she would need the EU to compromise and allow the entire UK, not just Northern Ireland, to remain inside the bloc&rsquos customs union.The Prime Minister&rsquos team are hopeful the UK would keep goods regulations in Northern Ireland closely aligned with the EU rules applying in the Republic.The Irish Border issue remains a major Brexit sticking point (Image: )There would be new regulatory checks on goods passing between Northern Ireland and the British mainland, where different rules could apply once Britain leaves the EU.Britain would hope to minimise checks by using technology to limit more intrusive goods inspections, where a compromise would see a distinction between customs and regulatory checks.A similar proposal was raised at an informal gathering of European leaders when Mr Barnier suggested he could accept to move checks inland, to avoid what is seen as a border in the Irish Sea.Under Brussels&rsquo current proposals for the so-called Irish backstop Northern Ireland would remain inside the EU&rsquos customs regime separate from the rest of Britain &ldquounless and until another solution is found in order to avoid a hard border from emerging after Brexit.                Irish border: &lsquoCommon sense and goodwill&rsquo can SOLVE key Brexit issue                David Davis mocked for claim &lsquoyou can buy pint using pounds in Dublin'Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said reports the government was preparing to back down on customs checks was &ldquooverspeculating.He told a conference fringe event: &ldquoOur number one priority is making sure we don&rsquot see a border down the Irish sea that will carve up economically the United Kingdom.&ldquoWe said we would need to retain a UK-wide customs backstop and on the regulatory side of things, we have been clear that we will, as long as we can carry the communities of Northern Ireland with us, we will be open to be looking at some of the options on regulatory checks.He also said he welcomed EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier&rsquos suggestion that technology could help resolve the border issue.

story: The venue itself is split across three main areas (Image: )On October 12, 28-year-old Princess Eugenie will wed Jack Brooksbank, 32, in a lavish ceremony at the Windsor chapel as millions watch on in awe.For many spectators and royal fans alike, it will be a chance to catch the golden couple in the moments before and after they become man and wife in front of the nation.Yet as well as the bride&rsquos show-stopping gown, the glamorous guest list and the romantic carriage ride attention should also be paid to the venue itself, which as well as being loaned to Eugenie and Jack, was also bestowed to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, for their May 19 wedding.Here, Express provides an intimate guide to the chapel to play host to two of the biggest royal weddings in one year.                Princess Eugenie wedding date: When is the royal wedding? How to watchThe venue itself is split across three main areas.The first, and the most well-known is the Quire, where cameras were installed to give viewers the chance to watch Harry and Meghan exchange their vows.Its aisles were finished and roofed between 1477 and 1483 and features an array of fascinating points of interest.Examples are the The Oriel Window, which was created by King Henry VIII so his his first wife, Katherine of Aragon, could look down and view services.On October 12, 28-year-old Princess Eugenie will wed Jack Brooksbank, 32, in a lavish ceremony (Image: )                How much will Princess Eugenie's wedding cost compare to Meghan's?The Garter Knights Stalls are also featured in the Quire. The Plate, fixed to the back of a stall to illustrate the arms and titles of a Knight or Lady, remains in place after their death and has resulted in the impressive and important display in the awe-inspiring room today.The nave is another of the main areas of the chapel and features magnificent tone vaulting not completed until 1528. It also features the West Window, the third largest in England.The Lower Ward is the main entrance of the chapel for visitors who upon travelling through, will be led to the Nave.Another eye-catching feature of St George&rsquos Chapel is the tomb of King Henry VIII, of which no expense as spared.The Garter Knights Stalls are also featured in the Quire (Image: )Plans for the vast edifice features &lsquofine Oriental stones&rsquo and resplendent with white marble pillars, gilded bronze angels, four life-size images of the King and Queen Jane, and a statue of the King on horseback under a triumphal arch, &lsquoof the whole stature of a goodly man and a large horse&rsquo.The beautiful congregation also includes a tragic tribute to the only child of George IV, who died during childbirth, and the subsequent death of Princess Charlotte, a stunning stone memorial was created for her in the Urswick Chapel. It features a woman reaching towards the skies as an angel cradles a baby nearby.Princess Eugenie&rsquos wedding to wine merchant Jack Brooksbank is just weeks away and excitement is hotting up.The royal has already confirmed her wedding dress will be designed by a UK-based designer, as opposed to Meghan who opted for French fashion house Givenchy for hers &ndash although her designer Clare Waight Keller is British.

story: Royal fans are speculating as to what colour the Queen will wear for Eugenie's wedding (Image: )Princess Eugenie will wed fianc&eacute Jack in an extravagant ceremony on October 12.&nbspThe Queen&rsquos granddaughter and ninth-in-line to the throne will marry in the same venue Prince Harry and Meghan Markle did, St George&rsquos Chapel in Windsor.&nbspHer two-day wedding will feature an A-list guest list, as well as a funfair complete with rides and cocktails.&nbspThis is the second royal wedding of the year, after Meghan Markle and Prince Harry&rsquos in May.&nbsp                Princess Eugenie wedding: The Queen lends venue to granddaughter                Princess Eugenie wedding: When will Royal Wedding be shown on TV?Whilst speculation is rife around the designer and style of Eugenie&rsquos dress, excitement is also growing as to what colour Queen Elizabeth will wear to her granddaughter&rsquos wedding.&nbspAccording to Ladbrokes, the latest odds point the Queen in the direction of donning blue for the big day.Ladbrokes spokesman Alex Apati said: Punters seem to think the Queen will go for blue on Eugenie's big day.&nbspCurrently blue for the monarch&rsquos colour of choice lies at 21, followed by pink at 31.Orange is in third at 41 followed by purple and then green at 51 and 61 respectively.&nbspSunny yellow and cream each sit at 61.Earlier in the year for grandson Harry&rsquos wedding to Meghan, the Queen wore a lime green dress and matching hat.&nbspThe Queen wore a flared dress in lime, lemon, purple and grey printed silk along with an edge to edge coat, both designed by Stewart Parvin.                The Queen reveals the worst day of her life                The Queen's first openly gay Royal Footman QUITS after demotionShe accessorised it with The Richmond Diamond Brooch.Her hat, designed by Angela Kelly, was adorned with purple flowers and handmade lace crystals and pearls.&nbspWhilst the colour the Queen has chosen won&rsquot become apparent until the big day, royal fans can be assured it will be a bold and bright colour choice.&nbspThe reason for this is so that crowds at events where the monarch is in attendance can spot her at a distance.&nbspThe Queen wore lime green to grandson Prince Harry's wedding (Image: )The wedding will take place at St George's Chapel in Windsor (Image: )This was made clear in the documentary The Queen at 90, when Sophie, Countess of Wessex spoke of her mother-in-law&rsquos colour choices.&nbspShe said: &ldquoShe needs to stand out for people to be able to say 'I saw the Queen.&rsquoDon't forget that when she turns up somewhere, the crowds are two, three, four, ten, 15 deep, and someone wants to be able to say they saw a bit of the Queen's hat as she went past.

story: The Tory MP for New Forest West revealed he was not surprised with efforts by Remainers to reverse the democratic vote of 17.4 million Britons in the 2016 Brexit referendum &ndash insisting &ldquotrue believers on either side will never let it rest.Speaking exclusively to Express from the Conservative Party Conference, Mr Swayne said: &ldquoIt has almost become a religion, this European Union thing.&ldquoIt is almost to the state where we are actually denying the existence of their god. That&rsquos what it is promoted amongst a small minority of people to be fair.The Brexiteer MP then hit back at claims that no Brexit deal will meet the demands of what the British people voted for.He added: &ldquoHold on a minute, I know what I voted for because I put my cross into the box.&ldquoI know how my constituents voted but I don&rsquot know what they voted for.&ldquoOverwhelmingly, they voted against something but as to what they actually wanted in its place is something that I can only speculate about.Mr Swayne then dismissed claims that all Brexiteers voted to completely cut ties with the EU.He said: &ldquoAnd I do get a little tired of people telling me exactly what the British people voted for. They don&rsquot know.Brexit news: Desmond Swayne says Brexit is like denying Remainers of their god  (Image: &bull)&ldquoFor years, my constituents have been telling me &lsquowe were robbed Mr Swayne in 1975 &ndash&nbspwe thought we were joining a common market&rsquo.&ldquoThe common market turned out to be a superstate. They voted to leave the superstate. Does that mean they would actually like to hold on to the common market? It was always the wrong market for me. I voted in 1975.&ldquoBut actually for many of my constituents they would be quite happy to holding on to some of those economic elements of the European Union.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab also mocked Remainers calling for a so-called People&rsquos Vote and &ldquobankrolling a campaign to scare the wits out of British people.The Brexiteer MP had Tories in stitches as he hit out at a group of staunch Remainers wanting to thwart the Brexit result during his keynote speech at the Conservative Party Conference on Monday.Mr Raab said: &ldquoRespecting the result &ndash that&rsquos the essence of our democracy. I have to say I am heartened by the fact that the majority of those who voted to Remain have accepted the referendum verdict.&ldquoFor them, the integrity of our democracy is far more important than winning or losing on any one inidual issue.&ldquoBut I will tell you what is not democracy. The efforts of a small but influential group of senior politicians and establishment figures to overturn the result of the referendum.He added: &ldquoThey want to stop us leaving. You can just picture them sitting in an expensive advertising agency discussing how to claim that black is white.Additional reporting by Thomas Hunt and Caitlin Collins in Birmingham.

title: Brexit news Theresa May UK EU Ireland border concession latest
story: The Prime Minister will make a dramatic new Irish backstop offer to Brussels, which will soften her approach to allowing a number of regulatory goods checks demanded by the European Union&rsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier.She will likely allow the EU&rsquos desired new checks on goods moving between British mainland and Northern Ireland in order to unblock deadlocked negotiations, according to a senior Government official.For her plan to work, she would need the EU to compromise and allow the entire UK, not just Northern Ireland, to remain inside the bloc&rsquos customs union, the source told Bloomberg.The Prime Minister&rsquos team are hopeful the UK would keep goods regulations in Northern Ireland closely aligned with the EU rules applying in the Republic.                Brexiteer MP issues STERN warning to BrusselsHowever, there would be new regulatory checks on goods passing between Northern Ireland and the British mainland, where different rules could apply once Britain leaves the EU.Britain would hope to minimise checks by using technology to limit more intrusive goods inspections, where a compromise would see a distinction between customs and regulatory checks.A similar proposal was raised at an informal gathering of European leaders when Mr Barnier suggested he could accept to move checks inland, in order to avoid what is seen as a border in the Irish Sea.Under Brussels&rsquo current proposals for the so-called Irish backstop Northern Ireland would remain inside the EU&rsquos customs regime separate from the rest of Britain &ldquounless and until another solution is found in order to avoid a hard border from emerging after Brexit.Brexit news: Theresa May is preparing concessions on the Irish border, according to UK source (Image: )Under Brussels&rsquo Irish backstop proposals Northern Ireland would remain inside EU&rsquos customs regime (Image: )Despite efforts by Mr Barnier to take the drama out the thorny issue, Mrs May has continued to instance no British Prime Minister would be able to accept his offer which effectively creates a new border in the Irish Sea, especially when her minority Government depends on the support of Ulster loyalists in the DUP.In July, the EU&rsquos negotiator placed an emphasis on goods rather than customs checks, explaining he has &ldquono intention to create a border in the middle of the UK and also wants to &ldquorespect the constitutional order of the UK.Despite posturing from both sides, one thing remains a constant: the Irish backstop must feature in any withdrawal deal, which would mean Britain crashes out of the EU without a transition period and Brussels would not receive its orce bill.A senior UK Government official speaking in Salzburg last month revealed the plans were being made ready for a British compromise to be presented to Brussels.                Brexiteer MP says Brexit is like 'denying Remainers of their god'                Jacob-Rees Mogg responds to Boris Johnson Tory leadership claimsTheresa May will reportedly climb down to allow the EU&rsquos desired new checks on goods at Irish border (Image: )They said: &ldquoThere are checks which take place already between Northern Ireland and Great Britain in relation to some agricultural products.&ldquoOn the Irish backstop, we have put forward our proposal in relation to customs backstop. We&rsquove been having discussions on that with the EU for a number of months now.&ldquoWe&rsquove always said that we will need to bring forward further proposals in relation to the regulatory aspects of the backstop. That will happen.Mrs May will now have to hope any compromise falls under the DUP&rsquos Brexit red lines for Northern Ireland to ensure their continued support in the House of Commons.DUP leader Arlene Foster has said: &ldquoOur only red line is that we are not treated any different from the rest of the United Kingdom, that there are no trade barriers put up between Northern Ireland and our biggest market &ndash which, of course, is Great Britain.

title: asda delivery driver Amy Natasha Botten Feltham west London 200 shop
story: Amy Natasha Botten, 20, of Feltham, west London, claims to have left her young son crying in her flat as was forced to walk down to the ground floor to collect her food shop.Filming the bizarre encounter, the mum-of-one, who is also four months pregnant with her second child, appears out of breath as she confronts Asda delivery driver who is seen emptying the contents of the crates containing the customer&rsquos shopping onto the floor.Unhappy with his refusal to carry her shopping upstairs and into her flat, she then posted the footage on Facebook where it has since gone viral.In the clip, she is seen telling the driver she is &ldquoheavily pregnant and asks him to &ldquobe a decent human being, yet the driver continues to tell her he will not carry the shop upstairs for her.Filming the bizarre encounter, she appears out of breath as she confronts the Asda delivery driver (Image: FACEBOOK)In the footage she said: &ldquoCan you not help me with this last little bit because my little boy is up there crying his eyes out?The driver responds: &ldquoI'd rather not.She is then heard saying: &ldquoYou'd rather not? But this is your job.Ms Botten also asked the driver why some of her shopping was not in any bags when he put it at the bottom of the stairwell.The driver is heard saying: &ldquoNo more bags.He then leaves without saying anything.After posting the video of her encounter on Facebook, Ms Botten wrote: &ldquoThis shouldn't be happening to anyone, bad health, lonely and elderly, disabled, pregnant!!&ldquoIt should NOT BE HAPPENING. It's called HOME delivery.The driver responds: &ldquoI'd rather not.  (Image: FACEBOOK)&ldquoI just had to carry &pound200 monthly shop up two flights of stairs alone, pregnant with pelvic problems. No choice but to leave my son on his own crying.She added: &ldquoFeltham asda gave me a bottle of champagne and some flowers and couldn&rsquot apologise enough for the driver not doing his job. (No I won&rsquot be drinking it and no I didn&rsquot record this for compensation).As Asda spokesman said: &ldquoWe always try to offer our customers great service but clearly we got it wrong on this occasion and we are truly sorry.&ldquoWe have offered our full apologies to Ms Botten and are in contact with her to try and make amends.

Thank God. It&rsquos almost 5am here in #Tokyo, #Kanto area. A new day, and month, is dawning!While Seema KM wrote: &ldquoWhat a night! The winds are now gone and it&rsquos quite outside!8.25pm: Japan warned of another typhoon on wayExperts have warned Japan is on the path of another typhoon - which could be the nation's seventh of the season.Typhoon Kong-rey is currently in the Pacific and could cause more damage to the disaster-hit region.It currently has the strength of a Category 3 hurricane, Japan has been warned.Typhoon Trami photo from space (Image: NASA)6pm: Nasa footage shows huge size of cycloneSpace agency Nasa has released images of Typhoon Trami from above.The staggering size of the cyclone is highlighted by the shocking images taken by astronauts on the International Space Station.Astronaut Alexander Gerst said: It looks as if somebody's pulled the planet's gigantic plug.5.42pm: Airline chaos revealedAirlines cancelled more than 1,200 flights over the chaotic weather.Kansai International Airport in Osaka, western Japan, which was heavily flooded by a typhoon in early September, said it had closed its runways from 11 a.m. (0200 GMT) on Sunday until 6amon Monday.The airport only fully reopened on September 21.5.15pm: Woman in 60s missing - more than 80 injuredA woman in her 60s has been reported missing in the Miyazaki prefecture of southern Hapan after being washed away in a paddy irrigation channel, according to NHK.More than 80 people were injured, it also said.Japan Meteorological Agency issued warnings of landslides and flooding from possible storm surges.Typhoon Trami: Map shows the latest path for the weather warning (Image: JMA)4.30pm:&nbsp Witnesses in Tokyo report 'noisy gusts'One witness from Tokyo has revealed the extent of the gusts hitting the region.Writing to Japan Times, the resident of the Hiroo district of the capital, said: &ldquoReally noisy wind gusts and rain in Hiroo 3 chome. Never heard anything like it!! Very happy not to be outside. I hope everyone stays safe!!Another Tokyo resident Jean-Yves Jault wrote on Twitter: &ldquoWind so strong right now I can feel air pressure changes in my ears inside my well-insulated Tokyo apartment, storm expected to pass about 3am.Heavy rains will then pound Tokyo with about 300mm of rainfall expected to hit on Monday night.3.40pm: Power outages affecting thousands in Kanto, northeast side of HonshuAbout 19,000 properties are without power in Kanto, according to NHK.Yamanshi Prefecture is the worst affected with 8,600 buildings currently without power.2.55pm: Torrential rain is pounding landfall in&nbspWakayama Prefecture in western JapanThe storm made landfall near the city of Tanabe, according to Japanese media reports.People are being advised to brace themselves for &ldquoextremely strong winds and torrential rain, NHK said.11.55am: Emergency phrase cards in six foreign languages issued to travellers in JapanNon-Japanese speakers stranded by Typhoon Trami have been urged to download one of the emergency phrase cards made available online.The cards have been made available in six languages - English, Indonesian, Chinese, Spanish, Korean, and Portuguese - and people can point to phrases on the card if they need emergency support.The cards are available to download from the website of&nbspEhime Prefecture International Center here - first select your language along the top bar.Typhoon Trami tracker LIVE updates: A woman struggles to stay upright on Kyushu island (Image: AFPGetty)11.15am:&nbspWhere is Trami now?Trami was located 18.6 miles (30km) and Kagoshima Prefectures.Most of the injuries were caused by flying glass and including a man in his thirties who suffered a severe cut to his leg.No deaths have been recorded.About 300,000 households are still without power in the regions.9.30am: All Tokyo train services to be suspended because of TramiTrain services in Tokyo will be cancelled from 12pm BST (8pm local time) in advance trees being bent by the strong winds (Image: The Asahi Shimbun via Getty)8.55am update: Where is Typhoon Trami now?Typhoon Trami is churning just southwest off Shikoku island and is expected to make title: Storm leslie tracker path noaa hurricane latest forecast weather
story: Leslie is fairly static in the Atlantic Ocean, but will reach hurricane status tomorrow (Image:  NOAA)Atlantic hurricane season began on June 1 ending on November 30, and is a time in which the Atlantic sees an increase in tropical cyclones.Currently swirling through the Atlantic is tropical storm Leslie, located 615 miles east of Bermuda.With maximum sustained winds of 60mph with higher gusts, Leslie is expected to move toward the west-southwest at 5mph.&nbspThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) have forecast that Leslie will strengthen to hurricane status by tomorrow (Tuesday).                Storm Rosa to SMASH Arizona TOMORROW: Nevada and Utah on ALERTThe weather experts said: &ldquoAdditional gradual strengthening is expected during the next 48 hours and Leslie is forecast to become a hurricane on Tuesday or Tuesday night.Meteorologists began tracking the subtropical system, which after strengthening was named Leslie, on September 23.&nbspAfter continuing to increase in strength, Leslie became a tropical storm on September 29.&nbspAs Leslie slowly drifts southward over the next few days, the subtropical system will find itself in slightly warmer waters, which will help to fuel and strengthen the system.&nbspThe Atlantic Ocean during October generally sees less tropical storm activity according to AccuWeather.However, Leslie will flout the rules by becoming a hurricane during the first week of October.&nbspThe tropical system has not moved much, staying within the Atlantic - a pattern which may continue this week.&nbspAccuWeather Meteorologist Steve Travis said: &ldquoLeslie will slowly drift southward over the next few days and is likely to become a hurricane by the middle of the week.                Typhoon Trami in PICTURES: Japan island Okinawa POUNDED by heavy rainHowever, on its path southward, Leslie will move into slightly warmer waters, which will then fuel and strengthen the system.According to NOAA, &ldquoTropical storm-force winds extend outward up to 175 miles (280 km) from the centre of Leslie.There will be no threat to land despite Leslie&rsquos strengthening to a hurricane in the coming days.Although some large waves and strong rip currents could impact on the island of Bermuda as well as some other areas this week.Hurricane Leslie will not make land but could trigger strong waves and rip tides at Bermuda (Image: WUNDERGROUND)October is a usually quiet month for hurricanes, but Leslie is the exception (Image: NOAA)NOAA said in their latest advisory: &ldquoLarge swells generated by Leslie will continue to affect portions of the southeastern coast of the United States, Bermuda, the Bahamas, and most of the Greater and the Lesser Antilles through&nbsptonight.The first hurricane of Atlantic hurricane season was Chris, which reached hurricane status on July 10, quickly strengthening to a category two hurricane on July 11.&nbspHurricane Chris was listed as attributing to the death of one man who drowned in rough seas at Kill Devil Hills in North Carolina.

title: south africa corruption ANC assassinations mandela Sindiso Magaqa Thabiso Zulu
story: Political assassinations in South Africa have surged (Image: )The University of Cape Town and the Global Initiative Against Transnational Crime has claimed members of Nelson Mandela&rsquos African National Congress (ANC) have turned to violence and as a result, 90 politicians have been killed since the start of 2016, more than twice the annual rate in the 16 years.Political assassinations in South Africa have surged, threatening the stability of hard-hit parts of the country and destroying Nelson Mandela&rsquos vision of a demarcating nation.Mary de Haas, an expert on political killings who taught at the University of KwaZulu-Natal said: &ldquoThe politicians have become like a political mafia.&ldquoIt is the very antithesis of democracy, because people fear to speak out.                South Africa land seizures: Ramaphosa vows to undo &lsquoCOLONIALIST&rsquo acts                South Africa fury after girl, seven, raped in restaurant bathroomOutlining the events of last year&rsquos shock assassination on Sindiso Magaqa, of which a suspect was arrested by police weeks ago, the New York Times spoke to whistleblower Thabiso Zulu, who opened up on the terrifying spike in hits put out on members of the African National Congress.Referring to the Italian Mafia, he said: &ldquoIf you understand the Cosa Nostra, you don&rsquot only kill the person, but you also send a strong message.Mr Zulu, who is now fearing for his own life after speaking out, added: &ldquoWe broke the rule of omert&agrave.He also said the late Mr Mandela&rsquos party had become like the mafia and that unlike the notorious 1990s when killings were driven by rivalries between political parties in the nation, they have now shifted towards corruption whistleblowers in a bid to silence them.Mr Magaqa and five other ANC politicians have been assassinated (Image: )South African police have begun releasing data on political murders for the first time this year in a bid to curb them and drum up further international attention.Mluleki Ndobe, mayor of KwaZulu-Natal, where Mr Magaqa and five other ANC politicians have been assassinated in the past year, spoke of the province that had been dubbed the deadliest of all after the party said 80 ANC officials were killed there between 2011 and 2017.He said: &ldquoIt was better before we attained democracy, because we knew the enemy &mdash that the enemy was the regime, the unjust regime.He added: &ldquoNow, you don&rsquot know who is the enemy.                South Africa ow ESCALATES as Ramaphosa calls Trump &lsquoill-informed'In the region, an ANC councillor was short dead last year, municipal manager was killed in March and last month a councillor and son of an ANC deputy mayor were charged in the killing of an ANC official who led anti-corruption protests.But few others have faced justice for their roles in the killings, the New York Times reports.

title: jean claude juncker italy budget eurozone european union
story: Jean-Claude JunckerMatteo Salvini (Image: )The cash-strapped country&rsquos new populist coalition government is threatening to rip up previous budget agreements with Brussels and aim instead for a public deficit of 2.4 per cent of gross domestic product, far higher than the 1.6 percent target indicated by finance minister Giovanni Tria.Mr Tria is now arguing Italy&rsquos economic growth will outperform EU forecasts insists debt will continue to fall that despite a rising deficit.But Mr Juncker has rejected Mr Tria&rsquos claims and urged him not to go ahead with the proposals.He said: Italy is distancing itself from the budgetary targets we have jointly agreed at EU level.                Euro on edge as Italy to face EU in showdown over budget                Italy debt crisis: Di Maio accuses EU of inciting budget 'terrorism'I would not wish that, after having really been able to cope with the Greek crisis, we'll end up in the same crisis in Italy. One such crisis has been enough.If Italy wants further special treatment, that would mean the end of the euro. So you have to be very strict.Italy's powerful deputy prime minister Matteo Salvini has already declared I do not care if the European Commission rejected the budget proposals.The leader of the nationalist League party, which shares power with the anti-establishment Five Star Movement, told supporters: No one in Brussels can tell me it is not time.&nbspIf Brussels says I cannot do it, I do not care. I will do it anyway.Jean-Claude Juncker has warned Italy could bring down the eurozone (Image: )But eurozone finance ministers, who gathered for talks in Luxembourg today, insisted all governments must respect the bloc&rsquos spending rules and demanded more detail from Rome on the budget plans.French economy minister Bruno Le Maire said the economic fate of all 19 eurozone members was linked and said the budget rule book was meant to protect countries from higher borrowing costs.Mr Le Maire said plans agreed on last week in Rome would need to be studied in detail by the European Commission, whose assessment would then be passed onto national capitals.He said: &ldquoI just want to make very clear that there are rules, and rules are the same for every state.                &lsquoNOT a challenge to Europe&rsquo Italy DEFENDS huge budget deficit                Italy vows to REDUCE public debt DESPITE spending increase&ldquoBecause our futures are linked, the future of Italy, France, Germany, Spain, Luxembourg, all the members of the eurozone are linked.Brussels is due to respond to the plans when they are formally submitted by mid-October but European Commission officials have already confirmed the Italian plans represent a &ldquovery significant deviation from commitments made by the country&rsquos previous administration.EU&rsquos economy commissioner Pierre Moscovici said: &ldquoWhat I note is that the Italian government seems to prioritise public expenditure.&ldquoWell, public expenditure can make you popular in the short term but in the end you have to be honest about who pays. It&rsquos always the citizens who pay.Italian finance minister Giovanni Tria arrives for talks in Luxembourg (Image: )Finland&rsquos finance minister Petteri Orpo said: &ldquoRules are for everyone. Everyone has to play by the rules.The eurozone sets overall targets of 3 percent annual deficits and commits countries to move toward 60 percent overall debt.Italy's debt currently stands at about 130 percent of GDP.

title: article 50 lisbon treaty brexit eu european council march 29 2019
story: Theresa May triggered our formal Article 50 exit notication in March 2017 to fire the starting gun on two years of tough negotiations. Heres the lowdown...As of 12.30pm on March 29 2017, the UK was set on a course to leave the EU by March 29, 2019.The PM sent an official letter invoking Article 50  which was delivered to Donald Tusk.It came after May quashed a Tory revolt after passing a law to authorise Brexit following a marathon five-week battle with Parliament.The Lords had earlier defied the PM by adding two changes to the bill which would guarantee the rights of EU citizens and ensure Parliament has a vote on the final deal - but the Commons threw out these conditions.But it backed down after the Commons vote, agreeing not to tamper with the landmark power - ordered by the Supreme Court - for a second time, ending the constitutional stand-off.On October 1 Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said a pause on leaving the bloc was not on the cards and called on EU chiefs to get real.The Lisbon Treaty came into force on December 1, 2009, as the culmination of the EUs eight-year quest to make the organisation more democratic, more transparent and more efficient.It set out a number of rules and posts including the introduction of the EU Presidency, redistribution of voting weights of member states and Article 50.Article 50 sets out the process of leaving the EU and states: Any Member State may decide to withdraw from the Union in accordance with its own constitutional requirements.It then goes on to say that a state wishing to withdraw will let the European Council know it intends to leave, which will trigger the article.At this point, the Treaties that bound Britain to EU rules cease to apply and the terms of leaving will begin to be negotiated.The law is not totally clear on this, but there are a few issues that could leave some wiggle room.One primarily being  a transitional deal is not secured with the EU to temporarily cover the countrys EU trade relations while the final deal is being negotiated.If the EU is unwilling to give the UK this deal, it would be an advantage for May to withdraw her request and then trigger it again - buying another two years of negotiations.Justice Secretary Liz Truss has said of Article 50 that it is her understanding that it is irrevocable.The UK Supreme Court has said once notice, Article 50, is given it cannot be withdrawn.However, Lord Kerr, author of Article 50, has said: You can change your mind while the process is going on.And the House of Lords, advised by its legal counsel, was told there is nothing in Article 50 to prevent a member state from reversing its decision.Former Labour cabinet minister Peter Mandelson has said the deadline will been to be extended.I think everyone knows none of this process is going to be completed by next March, everyone knows it’s going to have to be extended, Lord Mandelson told the BBCs Politics Live.Landmark EU orce talks are now underway, with long-term agreements over issues such as the Irish border still some way off.Former Brexit secretary David Davis and the EUs chief negotiator Michel Barnier kicked off the Brexit negotiations on Monday, June 19 2017 with a historic handshake in Brussels.On December 15, 2017, the EU agreed to move to the second phase of negotiations after reaching preliminary agreements on three of its major priorities the orce bill, the Irish border and the rights of EU citizens post-Brexit.An agreement on a transition period, or implementation period, was later reached. Theresa May and her Cabinet pushed for the arrangement to avoid a so-called clf edge moment on March 29, 2019.However, the agreement of the transition period has not been without dficulties.Fishermen and some MPs were left angry after it was confirmed that the current rules and regulations regarding EU nations access to British fishing waters would remain largely unchanged.After triggering Article 50 it is supposed to take two years to completely leave the EU but many experts think it could take far more time.Invoking the article fires the starting gun on leaving but there will then follow series of complicated negotiations.The terms of exit have to be agreed between the UK and the 27 other member states who all have a veto over the conditions of leaving.After that, it will then have to be approved in each of the national parliaments meaning French, Irish or Dutch MPs could, in theory, scupper the process.David Davis announced that Britain will officially leave the EU at 11pm GMT on March 29, 2019 - this date is now exactly six months away.The Article 50 bill passed through the final House of Commons hurdle in January, when a majority of 372 MPs out of 494 voted in favour.More than 50 Labour MPs voted against the legislation, and just one Conservative - Ken Clarke.This shows the full list of who voted for and against.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jacob rees mogg children vandalised house brexit
story: The MP for North East Somerset caused controversy after airing his views on abortion and gay marriage. Then, on August 2018 his Somerset home was vandalised. Heres his story.Jacob Rees-Mogg is a backbench Tory MP for North East Somerset but is better known for his period drama persona which has been winning him fans.He entered parliament during the 2010 General Election after working as a fund manager in London.During the EU referendum, he was a passionate Brexiteer and made many high-profile media appearances arguing for a vote to leave the EU.To say he was born into a privileged position is an understatement - he is the Eton and Oxford-educated son of the long-serving Times editor William Rees-Mogg.During the 1997 General Election Rees-Mogg attracted ridicule.This is because he brought his faithful nanny along with him as he battled to be elected in the working class and staunchly Labour seat of Central Fe.He has batted away speculation that he would challenge Theresa May for the leadership of the party, insisting he was completely loyal to her.Rees-Mogg said he was more likely to become POPE than PM.On October 1 he also said changing Conservative leader could cause more problems than it solves and the party should back May.He said the Torys lack of a parliamentary majority meant it would be dficult for an alternative leader to push through an ambitious Brexit deal.Outside the political arena, Jacob is a family man with six children.His we is journalist Helena de Chair, daughter of the aristocrat Somerset de Chair.He celebrated the birth of his sixth child with a touching picture on Instagram in September 2017.He wrote: Helena and I announce with great joy that we have a baby Sixtus Dominic Bonace Christopher, a brother for Peter, Mary, Thomas, Anselm and Alfred.In May 2018 it was reported by The Mail on Sunday that he had purchased a new £5million house just around the corner from No 10 Downing Street.The five-storey mansion is just a short walk away from the Parliament and is also close to Tory HQ in the heart of Old Westminster.Rees-Mogg joked he had been priced out of swanky Mayfair and needed a bigger home for his six children.Rees-Mogg named his sixth child Sixtus, which is a Roman name meaning polished.It is also the name of a Pope and Saint.His full name is Sixtus Dominic Bonace Christopher .Sixtus eldest sibling is Peter Theodore Alphege, who was born in 2007.Jacobs only daughter Mary Anne Charlotte Emma came along a year later followed by Thomas Wentworth Somerset Dunstan in 2010 and Anselm Charles Fitzwilliam in 2012.His fth child, Alfred Wulfric Leyson Pius, was featured in a video as his father tried to teach him how to say Brexit.Alfred was born in February 2016.In September 2018, a thug shouted at the children your daddys a horrible person outside their London home.It happened on August 1, 2018, when the Rees-Mogg family were on holiday in the US.According to the police, graffiti was sprayed on a building and on a car as well as the garden.They managed to write posh scum on windows of the house.The MPs 17th Century country home, called Gournay Court, is a listed building.He also owns a £5.6m house in Westminster.Due to his strict Catholic beliefs, Mogg admitted on ITVs Good Morning Britain that he did not support abortion even in the case of rape and incest.I am completely opposed to abortion, le begins at conception, he said.Abortion is morally indefensible.The MP has also repeatedly voted against sex marriage legislation.He defended everyones right to free speech, and insisted that  he ever became Prime Minister, the law is not going to change.Soon after Rees-Mogg made his remarks it emerged the millionaire MP was making money out of an abortion pill despite his strong stance against it.Somerset Capital Management, the investment company he co-founded, owns nearly £5million of shares in Indonesian firm Kalbe Farma.Reacting to the story, Rees-Mogg told The Mirror: This is not something I would wish to invest in personally but you have a duty as an investment manager not to impose constraints on investors.He added: This company does not procure the abortion of babies.It’s not my money in these investments and I profit from the total amount of client money we hold, not the investments we make.The Made in Chelsea star and 2017 Im A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here winner has admitted she has the hots for Rees-Mogg.In an interview with the Sunday Times, Georgia Toff Toffolo revealed the politicians she admired “the standard - Zac Goldsmith, Jacob Rees-Mogg. I fancy them all, adding: Jacob’s a sex god.”The reality star elaborated: “The human mind can be sexy. He’s so clever, I just love him, adding: “I fancy middle-aged politicians, but I’ve never been with one.”Rees-Mogg has responded to news of the 23-year-olds crush, saying he was “greatly surprised but nonetheless flattered” by the revelation.“I am glad Miss Toffolo won and hope this is the launchpad for a glittering career,” he added.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: james forsyth no home comforts to ease the brexit bind
story: In the bars and on the fringe, vigorous argument will rage about what the best Brexit option is for Britain.Cabinet ministers will whisper in corridors about what the Government should do next. Boris Johnson will draw a big crowd for his “Chuck Chequers” rally.But there is a bigger danger waiting in the wings for the Tories: They simply don’t have a domestic agenda big enough for the moment.Labour has, over the past few days, set out its vision for Britain. It is, in places, scary. But give Jeremy Corbyn and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell this, it is undoubtedly clear and bold. As one Cabinet minister says, half admiringly:  “They’re hungry.”The Tories need to show  they have a better plan, one that will deal with people’s concerns— and they don’t have any time to waste. As one minister warns: “I’m just really terried. People don’t realise what a big deal this is.”The Tory Party’s problem is that it isn’t giving the country a vision of where it wants to take it. One former party leader has taken to lamenting that the Tories have “lost the narrative”.At conference last year, Theresa May declared that it was her mission to solve the housing crisis, to restore the British dream of home ownership for the many.But in the past 12 months, the Government has made far too little progress on this. Yes, some sensible steps have been taken. But the policies that will really solve this crisis, proper planning reform and a massive, Government-led housebuilding programme, haven’t happened.The result of all this: Jeremy Corbyn gets closer to power. As this newspaper revealed yesterday, Labour is now ahead in the seats that decide general elections thanks to its massive lead among renters.The likelihood of someone in their late twenties or early thirties on an average salary owning their own home has halved in the past 20 years.This is an electoral time bomb for the Tories. They can’t expect those without capital, or any prospect of getting it, to be capitalists.By the time of the next election, the Tories need to show people that their lives are getting better AND explain the damage  Corbyn would do to the country.One minister points the finger of blame at Number 10 for the Tory predicament. “A fish rots from the head down,” he tells me. But the Cabinet can’t escape its share of the blame, either.With a few exceptions, min­isters aren’t doing enough to take on Labour’s arguments. As one former Secretary of State fumed to me during Labour conference: “It’s outrageous. Where are the Cabinet?”If the Tories get Brexit wrong, it could cost them the next election. But even  they get a decent deal, it won’t guarantee them victory. For the public will vote on domestic issues — whether the housing crisis is solved, the state of the health service and what is going on with schools.Corbyn has simple answers to all these questions: They might be wrong, but they are answers. The Tories now need to show the country  they have answers too.AT last, some positivity and optimism about this country’s post-Brexit future from the Government.I can reveal  it is planning a major new festival celebrating the UK for 2022. The aim is for this festival to tell the world a story about Britain as we leave the EU and take charge of our own future. It is meant to coincide with the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee and the Commonwealth Games, which will be held in Birmingham that year.Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright,  who is pushing this idea in Whitehall, has told colleagues  it will be: “Future-facing, telling a story about the UK’s unique strengths, particularly as a place to invest, as we forge a new future outside the European Union.”If the Government gets it right, this festival could be a great statement about the open, dynamic country that Britain is going to be after Brexit. It should emphasise how this country is going out into the world after leaving the EU, not pulling up the drawbridge.The aim should be to put on something that stands comparison with the great post-war Festival of Britain in 1951 or even the Great Exhibition of 1851, which showcased Victorian Britain’s global reach and technological edge.One Secretary of State, who is backing the idea, tells me: “People just want something really positive.”But cynics might note that there is an advantage for the Tories in a feel-good festival in an election year.But I understand he will  have a harsh message for the Westminster politicians in attendance. He will  tell them to stop bickering and positioning and get on with delivering for the country.Mr Street will say that outside the Westminster bubble, the public just want politicians to get on with things, rather than constantly jostling for position.What makes his  speech so interesting is that he is a Downing Street favourite. Indeed, I understand  some of those close to Theresa May are pushing for a similar tone in her speech.They believe  her post-Salzburg speech went down so well with the public not just because she was standing up to the EU but because she was taking charge and being that “bloody dficult woman”. They think she should use her speech to tell members  they won’t get everything  they want from the Brexit talks, but that she will get the best deal for Britain.Others, though, are wary of this approach. One Cabinet minister cautions that after last year, May should play it safe as “you can’t have two bad years  in a row”.THE Government has rightly guaranteed that the three million EU citizens living in Britain will be able to stay in the event of no deal.This is sensible. These citizens contribute a lot to this country, and help keep our economy and our public services moving.But it is also right that the Government is now discussing what the rules will be for deporting EU citizens who commit crimes after Brexit in a no-deal scenario.The details have not yet been decided and, as one government source puts it: “No one wants people deported for getting a parking ticket.”But it is right that those who are convicted of a signicant offence are removed.• SPOT the leadership bid will be one of the games  the Tories play in Birmingham.Any Cabinet minister who starts talking about their childhood will be accused of planning a run for the top job.  This leaves ministers walking a tightrope as they prepare their speeches. Some are dealing with this challenge by handing their time  to others.Penny Mordaunt, the Aid Secretary, is simply introducing a series of “British heroes” who do development work.But one of those involved in conference planning suspects that even this is about leadership as Mordaunt “doesn’t want to spend 45 minutes defending the aid budget to a hall of Tory activists”.James Forsyth is political editor of The Spectator.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
