title: glamour model reveals trade secrets
story: NewsGlamour model and former lap dancer, 38, reveals the secrets of the tradeTanya Cox, from Hull, has been working in the industry for 11 years and says she's now breaking into the 'mature market' of glamour modellingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie CorcoranSophie Kitching09:34, 1 OCT 2018Updated21:59, 1 OCT 2018NewsTanya Cox, 38, has revealed the trade secrets of working as a glamour model "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA glamour model has revealed the secrets of the trade from what working on shoots is really like to meeting women who start modelling topless in their 50s. Tanya Cox, 38, from Hull, has been working in the industry since she was 27 but says she often thinks about getting a real job. She was scouted as a glamour model while working as a lap dancer and says her past experience enabled her to be comfortable in front of the camera. Despite loving her job, Tanya says she thought about giving up her career when jobs dried up after she turned 30, reports the Hull Daily Mail. However, she's now finding success again as she breaks into the 'mature market'. How did you get into modelling and was it something you always wanted to do? I never really thought about doing any modelling work but whilst I was working as a lap dancer, I got approached by an agency and was asked  I would consider doing any modelling work.     I was quite shocked as I thought you had to be tall and skinny to do any kind of modelling but they reassured me that was just the fashion industry and that I was perfect for glamour. How old were you and how long have you been doing it? I came into the industry at 27 and I’m now 38. What was it like at first and what kind of things you were doing? Having already worked as a lap dancer for three years, I was very comfortable with modelling straight away. I think its the taking your clothes off bit that worries most new glamour models but as I had already been doing that for three years, that was the easy part, it was learning to find the light and what angles suited me that took the time the learn. Was you aware of any challenges the industry faced at the beginning? No, when I first came into the industry, everything seemed great, people were much more reliable with higher standards always putting quality first back then. But now its more quantity over quality and trying to get as much as possible shot in the time frame are booked for. Was there ever a point where you regretted getting into modelling? When I first turned 30, my work really quietened off as some companies considered me too old for the young market but I still looked too young to break the mature market. It was a very low point in my le and feeling my career slip away made me so depressed at times that I wished I never started. What has been the best things about it? Are there any moments which stand out where you loved it? I think for me, it helped me to find my own inner strength. I was guilty of never sticking up for myself when I was younger but now I'm the first to say when anyone is out of order, whether it's towards myself, a friend or even a stranger. Also through modelling and dancing, I have now met the best friends that I have ever had. I trust them completely and never doubt anymore that they all love me, as much as I love them. What has been some of the worst things about it? The worst thing about modelling is the high cancellation rates which has been getting worse and worse each year since 2010, but I don't think that is just an industry problem, I think society in general has forgotten its manners because I have noticed that more and more people cancel social meets with friends than ever before too.  Have you ever been judged based on your career? What do you think of that? Not in my personal le, but since my work started to quieten off and I have been trying to get a 'normal job', I do feel like employers are discriminating against me as I don't even seem to be able to get an interview these days, and when I was younger I always found it so easy to get work. When a place I worked at closed down, I had a new job within a week. How successful have you been? I felt pretty successful when I was younger but I do think I would of had a better career had I started when I was younger as it only lasted a few years before my peak ran out. I am now just starting to finally break the mature market, so fingers crossed I can make a success of that, but early days yet. Modelling must have changed since you started - have you seen that and in what way? It certainly has, all the technology keeps changing, I don't know how the photographers keep up. And unfortunately the budgets aren't as big anymore. I really miss the days of make-up artists and clothing departments on all shoots, but these days its only the very biggest companies that provide those now and for most shoots we just get a list of what types clothing to bring with us and have to do our own hair and make-up. Do you think it will change in the future and in what way? We are seeing dferent types of models coming through now We are and I love that we are now celebrating ersity with models now coming in dferent shapes, sizes, styles and ages. I met a new model on set recently who had just started doing topless modelling at 52. Social media has also come to the forefront and many models experience trolling - is that something you've experienced? Yes, I have had a few negative comments but, for every bad comment I get, there is always at least 20 positive comments to counter-act it and the troll then usually ends up getting loads of grief for his/her comment anyway so it always back fires on them.  Would you advise someone to get into the industry? What would your advice be and how would they go about getting a break? Although when times are good, it's not just a job to me, it is my le and I do love modelling but because of how dficult I have found trying to find a 'normal job' since, no I wouldn't recommend anyone getting into the industry. But  someone is 100 per cent certain that it's what they want to do, I recommend joining the online portfolio sites over an agency so you can speak to the photographers you are shooting for direct yourself as the agencies don't always give you the right information. Just make sure you always check references and remember you should never do anything that your not comfortable with. Is age a big thing in modelling and have you ever felt stigmatised by others in the industry? There is definitely more work for younger models, but thanks to films like American Pie making MILFS, GILFS and Cougars sexy, it has opened up the industry to mature models too which is great but the down side is that once your above 30, everyone feels the need to point out the fact that your older by using the terms MILF/Cougar etc alongside all your publications. I am still struggling with this eight years on as I keep getting called a MILF and find the term really offensive. Looking back now, do you feel empowered by it all? I feel that the industry has helped me to realise that it is OK to just be myself and that my imperfections make me human, approachable and more relatable. What agency are you with? I'm not with any agencies anymore. They did help get me work when I was new but once you are established, the bookings come to you direct and I also had a problems with been given the wrong information and been sent on jobs for levels I don't cover.

story: NewsTwo out of five teachers would leave Britain 'next term'  they got the right job opportunity abroadA survey of more than 1,000 teachers revealed over two thirds would consider working abroadShare&nbspByMark Ellis00:00, 2 OCT 2018News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo out of five teachers would quit Britain as soon as “next term” to work abroad  the right job came up, a survey shows. The top reasons for moving abroad include work-le balance, bureaucracy, lack of respect for teachers, government policy and disruptive pupils. A study by Tes magazine based on a survey of 1009 teachers reveals over two thirds  would consider working abroad.  Teachers in core subjects including English , maths  and science  teachers all say they would consider moving abroad within a term The findings come at a time when pupil numbers in secondary schools are rising, which is already projected to mean an extra 47,000 teachers will be needed by 2024. Work-le balance was the biggest reason for teachers in most subjects, maths teachers revealed their biggest frustration is a lack of respect for the profession . A lack of respect for teachers also peaked in importance among those reaching five years’ experience - a point at which official data shows many qualied teachers exit the profession for good. The survey revealed that secondary teachers were less happy than primary, with 41% saying they would move, compared to 29% of primary colleagues. English teachers were more likely to consider a move  than humanities , maths  or science teachers . Between 2011 and 2017, the number of teachers quitting within five years rose from just under a quarter to around a third.

story: NewsWomen are 'closing the infidelity gap': Why 'more and more wives are cheating on their husbands'Increasing numbers of women are prepared to act on their thoughts of other men -despite still loving their other halves, an author claimsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans14:37, 1 OCT 2018News" content="https:i2-prod.mirror/incoming/article8540226.ece/ALTERNATES/s615/3_Couple-in-bed.jpg"/More and more women are said to be cheating on their spouses  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWomen are closing the infidelity gap, experts believe. They are now reportedly more likely to cheat than three decades ago, with increased autonomy, earning power and opportunity. Women are 40 per cent more likely now to cheat on their husbands than in 1990, says best-selling author, Wednesday Martin. She adds that it appears rising numbers of women are prepared to act on their thoughts of other men, despite being in marriages. Wednesday, whose new book 'Untrue' is out this month, came across a number of real women’s voices and stories when carrying out research.   In a piece for the Daily Mail , she describes how one woman, called Erica, didn't want to give up on her marriage when the passion disappeared.  Instead, after years of sexual disappointment, the 46-year-old went online to search for someone - and ended up having a passionate affair. Wednesday says the women she encountered had ying problems, from 'routine' sex that didn't fulfil them, to no intimacy, to a craving for novelty. Crucially, none of these women wanted to give up on their marriages or loved their husbands any less, explains the author. While male infidelity used to be at a much higher rate than female infidelity, experts believe the gap is increasingly narrowing. One reason is that more women are out at work, where they are apart from their partners and exposed to potential lovers, some experts say. Another reason could be technology - with women able to discreetly have affairs through social media and apps, according to Wednesday.  And some believe women in long-term relationships are just as likely to lose interest in their other halves over time as men are. Wednesday says that what she has discovered through research is that women’s libidos are far stronger and more adventurous than we thought. Her research included speaking to women of a range of ages, as well as investigating scientic and evolutionary theories. In her Mail article, she says some scientists believe women get bored of sleeping with the same man, and desire others, for evolutionary reasons. Police in Odessa, Texas were called to a hotel room where they found a two-month-old buried under pillows and blankets.  The dad is also accused of beating his daughter but he absconded before the cops arrived. Local outlet WQAD reports authorities have now arrested the fugitive Texan father. They said Johnnie Lee Carter, 29, was arrested Monday in El Paso on a felony charge of injury to a child causing serious bodily injury, according to the Odessa Police Department. The news channel said Carter ran after police were called to a domestic incident on September 16.  It is claimed in court documents that he had choked and punched the little girl before applying super glue to her face.

title: indonesia tsunami scene total destruction
story: NewsIndonesia tsunami: Scene of total destruction along the coastline as rescue teams still try to reach stranded villagesSo far 840 people have been confirmed dead, but that number is expected to rise steeply in coming daysShare&nbspByTom Parry20:00, 1 OCT 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/indonesia-earthquake-grim-mass-grave-13339427,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the scene of almost total destruction along the coastline of Palu following the devastating earthquake and tsunami. The dramatic aerial image gives a stark illustration of the immense clear-up job facing the authorities in Indonesia, as emergency workers comb through the wreckage in a desperate search for survivors. Many people were trapped under fallen masonry and rubble from the earthquake before the tsunami struck. Resident Nur Indah said: “The ground rose up like a spine and suddenly fell. People were trapped and buried under collapsed houses. I could do nothing to help.”  Today – four days after the 20ft high wave surged through the city on Friday – Indonesian soldiers began digging a 300ft long trench as a mass grave for the hundreds of dead. So far, 840 people living in the city of more than 300,000 people are confirmed to have been killed, but that figure is expected to climb steeply in the coming days. Army commander Tiopan Aritonang said 545 bodies for the grave would be brought from one hospital alone. Willem Rampangilei, chief of Indonesia’s National Disaster Mitigation Agency, said: “This must be done as soon as possible for health and religious reasons.” As a majority Muslim country, burials are supposed to take place within one day in Indonesia. There are also fears that without immediate burial of the dead, disease could spread quickly among the tens of thousands made homeless. The tsunami was triggered by a 7.5 magnitude earthquake in the early evening, at the top of the narrow bay in which Palu is situated.  Britain sent a team of five specialist aid workers to assist the relief effort. International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt said: “Following a request from the Government of Indonesia... we are deploying a team of UK aid humanitarian advisers to the region, who will use their disaster response expertise to help co-ordinate efforts on the ground. “I have made an initial &pound2million of UK aid support available to help meet the immediate needs of the most vulnerable people.” Two survivors were pulled from the 80-room Hotel Roa Roa and there are hopes more could be alive after calls for help were heard.

Residents in Kozino village near Moscow, Russia say the puma was the pet of a local oligarch in a nearby elite housing compound Fryaz, home to many Russian celebrities. The male cat escaped and terrorised homes in Kozino in the early morning attack. It spent an hour and a half in local man Alexey Mirankov’s garden before the emergencies services shot the beast with a tranquilliser. Incredibly, the dog called Zhulya survived its ordeal - as it  the puma was toying with it rather than intending to feast on it.  “I heard my dogs yelping,” he said.   “When I went out, I saw a puma holding one of them in its teeth,” said the shocked householder. “I felt lost at first. “I immediately thought of my daughter aged five who is usually walking outside at this time - but thankfully she was in the house. “When I went back inside, the puma ran after me holding my dog with its teeth.  “It did not let the dog go for about eight minutes. When I got inside the house, I immediately called the emergency services.” The puma had stalked his garden from 6.30am looking for the hiding dogs, he said. “The rescue service came and shot at puma with a tranquilliser. “They said it was a young male who escaped from the elite settlement called Gryaz.

title: as it happens dundee united v ross county
story: Cries of &#8216Csaba out&#8217 rang around Tannadice as United slumped to an embarrassing defeatShambolic, abject, and abysmal are all words that can be used to describe Dundee United&#8217s performance as they were humiliated on their own patch by Ross County.The Terrors were hopeless at the back and pretty blunt going forward as the Staggies romped to all three points. It is hard to defend United manager Csaba Laszlo now and it would be no surprise  he is given his jotters after this most horric of days.It started when eventual hat-trick hero and former Tangerine Billy Mckay opened the scoring from close range on 11 minutes, knocking in a Josh Mullin cross.The only chink of light in the game came six minutes later as Pavol Safranko got on the end of Fraser Aird&#8217s delivery to guide the ball past Scott Fox in the away net.From there United laboured and County took advantage. Scoring the most simple and avoidable goals &#8211 often carbon copies of each other.The second came on 29 minutes after a Jamie Robson mistake played in Mullin to square for Mckay to knock in.On 41 minutes the same problems United had faced all game down their left-hand side were there for all to see as Sean Kelly inswinging free-kick went all the way through past Matej Rakovan in the home net. A horrible goal to concede with no communication evident and the defence at sixes and sevens.Soon after the restart the Staggies put the game to bed when Mullin and Mckay linked up again with the former this time tapping in from a yard out on 50 minutes.Mullin turned provider, once more, two minutes later laying Mckay&#8217s hat-trick on a plate for him and the Northern Irishman gobbled it up from a matter of inches out.Csaba tried to change things for the Tangerines, but by this point the punters had seen enough and were leaving in their droves and calling for his head in the process, as he brought on Stewart Murdoch and Fraser Fyvie to try to change things on 56 minutes.And three minutes later Murdoch summed up the Terrors afternoon as he was shown a straight red for a stamp on Jamie Lindsay.It capped what was United&#8217s worst performance in years as County saw out the rest of the game with little problem. Is it time up for Csaba?Full details in live blog.&nbsp

title: bus drivers from national express hq in birmingham drafted in to help dundee shortage
story: Drivers from the Midlands are being brought to Dundee to try to ease the city’s bus crisis.The Tele understands that five bus drivers from Birmingham arrived in the city this week to drive Xplore Dundee buses.A spokeswoman for the transport company has confirmed that they are being brought in to ease the problems caused by a shortage of drivers.She said: “National Express has centres in Dundee, the West Midlands and Coventry.“It makes sense for us to use bus drivers from these other centres while we have a shortage in Dundee.“We are doing everything we can to ease the disruption to bus services which we are currently facing.”However, the spokeswoman declined to confirm how many drivers had arrived in the city from south of the border.She added: “We maintain our stance that we are working hard, using what measures we can to resolve the immediate issues.”Last week, the Tele reported that dozens of bus cancellations had occurred in Dundee in the last few weeks, causing inconvenience for local commuters.North East councillor Brian Gordon said that his constituency had been particularly badly hit, with 30 services cut over two days last week.He said: “I welcome the fact that Xplore are doing something to deal with this.“However, there are two issues with the English drivers.“One is that they don’t know the routes in Dundee and they’re not going to learn them overnight.“Secondly,  it is just five drivers then that isn’t enough.“Many bus drivers in Dundee are complaining that they are missing out signicantly on holiday days due to them because of the shortage.“Five extra drivers isn’t going to resolve this.”

title: csaba happy to be able to call on quality as dundee united prepare for ross county
story: Boss Csaba Laszlo will be pleased to be able to turn to his bench for support as his Dundee United side host Ross County at Tannadice.Csaba will welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold after he missed last Saturday’s 2-0 win over Falkirk due to him not being risked on the articial surface so soon after recovering from a knee injury.He will be joined in the matchday party by winger Billy King as a few other absentees fight back to contention.“With these players coming back it will create more competition and up the quality in training,” Csaba said.“Sam Stanton and Stewart Murdoch are back in training with the team, while Nicky Clark will need another week.“It is important to get these players back to speed.”On Fyvie, Csaba added: “It was a frustration to have a player that can’t play.“We also have to accept that he is a player who has been injured long-term.“It has not just been an easy injury that takes a little time to recover from.“Psychologically, you must also be ready for this kind of match.“As a manager, you have to accept it when a player says ‘This isn’t the best game for me, on the articial pitch’.“For that reason he didn’t play but he will be OK for the Ross County match.”One player Csaba has, sadly, ruled out for the forseeable future is Lewis Toshney.“He has been out for a year so it is not easy for him.“He is fighting to come back.“I am happy that he can train but I don’t think we can talk just now about the first team.”

title: dundee gaffer neil mccann hoping lengthy injury list eases for crunch hamilton clash
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is hoping his walking wounded recover in time for today’s vital Premiership game against Hamilton kicks off.The Dens gaffer is under pressure to arrest his side’s run of straight defeats – six in the league, seven in all competitions – as the Dark Blues head to Lanarkshire to take on Accies.Martin Canning’s men sit on six points and can move nine clear of their relegation rivals with a second win in two, after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren last week.Neil will have at least one addition to his options after winger Roarie Deacon declared himself available for action.After a y period out, caused by an injury to his ankle picked up in the last game of last season against Partick which required surgery, it’s likely the former Arsenal man will have to settle for a place on the bench.Last week’s 3-0 defeat to Hibs saw Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all limp off.Finnish striker Kallman’s problem was cramp and won’t keep him out today while Madianga and Miller’s injuries were muscle based and it remains to be seen how long they may be out for.The club are hopeful Josh Meekings will be back fit after a thigh injury picked up against Motherwell four weeks ago.He missed the defeat to Hibs, though, Neil may be tempted to stick with his two loan signings Andy Boyle and Ryan Inniss in any case.At the top end of the field, the Dens boss will be hoping targetman Sofien Moussa has recovered from his knock picked up before the loss to Hibs to give him another option in attack.Meanwhile, Kenny Miller will serve the final game of his two-match suspension today.

title: dundee united sack manager csaba laszlo
story: Dundee United have parted company with manager Csaba Laszlo following yesterday&#8217s 5-1 home thumping by Ross CountyThe club and Csaba have mutually agreed to end his contract effective today, with No 2 Laurie Ellis taking over on an interim basis.Dundee United chairman Mike Martin said: &#8220I would like to thank Csaba for the considerable commitment he showed during his time at Dundee United and for his contribution to improving the underpinning football structure at the club.&#8220We wish him all the best for the future. I can also confirm that Laurie Ellis has taken interim management responsibility for the team.&#8221Ellis will likely be in the dugout for Saturday&#8217s trip to face Ayr United in the Ladbrokes Championship as the Terrors look to appoint a replacement for Csaba.The Hungarian took up the post himself on November 8 last year and leaves the Tangerines sitting fourth in the table and five points behind leaders Ayr.&nbsp

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make a  to the city.The 50-times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November 29.Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance to  to the national team at 43 years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park 18 years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although 33-years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September 2000, a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in 2009.The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No 33 shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £33.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet &amp Greet briefs – are on sale from 9am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.&nbspHelp For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

title: exclusive laurie ellis to be given chance to become permanent dundee united boss
story: Caretaker boss Laurie Ellis is set to be given the chance to show he’s the man to lead Dundee United on a permanent basis.The Tangerines’ assistant boss has been put in interim charge following yesterday’s sacking of Csaba Laszlo.He’s expected to lead the team into Saturday’s clash with Championship leaders Ayr United at Somerset Park.And the 38-year-old could be given more games to show he should have the job on a permanent basis. 100vw, 576px" /Get today&#8217s Tele for more on this story.&nbsp

title: hamilton boss martin canning wont be shed a tear for under pressure dundee counterpart neil mccann
story: Hamilton boss Martin Canning insists he cannot afford to take any notice of Neil McCann’s plight ahead of Saturday’s clash with bottom side Dundee.Pressure is piling on the Dens Park manager after six straight Ladbrokes Premiership defeats and a Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United.However, Canning noted his side beat St Mirren 3-0 at home on Saturday for their first win in four matches, to give Accies some respite of their own.He said: “You’ve got to go and do your own job and my job on Saturday is to try to get Hamilton Accies three points and  we can do that we’ll be delighted.“That’s just football. We know Dundee will be desperate for the points.“We’ve got to make sure we match that and that gives us the best opportunity.“We’re all going to have spells when things don’t go our way.“I’m pretty sure, same as I do, he’ll believe in his players that they can go and win games and he’ll work hard to try to make that happen.“One result can make you feel a lot better.“I think at times last season, half-a-dozen clubs went through runs of losing four, five, six games and it can happen in this league quite easily.“I thought Dundee were good against St Mirren – very good.“The goalkeeper makes a mistake and they lose the game and from there it snowballs into a poor run of results, so it can happen so easily.“The flip side of it is, you go and win two or three games in a row and it’s a completely dferent complexion.”

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to give themselves an easier ride
story: Neil McCann has urged his players to “give themselves an easier ride” at Hamilton on Saturday as they search for a first result of the campaign.The Dark Blues have endured a woeful start to the Premiership season, losing their opening six fixtures and scoring just twice.At the start of that run was also a 3-0 home defeat in the Betfred Cup to Ayr United, making it seven defeats on the trot.In none of those matches have Dundee managed to put themselves in front and their gaffer is desperate for the players to at least give themselves a chance of picking up a result.In order to do that, they’ll have to get the better of an Accies side high on confidence after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren in match that has had a bit of extra spice over the past few years.And despite extra pressure on him to get the result, Neil still has faith in his side.He said: “It’s a huge game, they always have been against Hamilton.“The games against Livingston, Hamilton, Kilmarnock are going to be so important and then Hibs and Hearts.“We are still striving for that first win and we’ll keep trying to give everything to get ourselves that first goal that can at least put ourselves in a position to go and get that first win.“I still think that you could see in the first 45 minutes last Saturday, there is a team there.“I would just love to see them give themselves an easier ride by putting themselves in front.”The Dens gaffer is also hopeful of having some extra bodies back fit after a punishing injury-hit spell.Josh Meekings, Genseric Kusunga, Nathan Ralph and Sofien Moussa all missed the defeat to Hibs with injury while Kenny Miller was suspended.He’ll also miss Saturday’s trip to Hamilton while Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all added to the injury worries last weekend.The good news is winger Roarie Deacon is nearing a  after getting 45 minutes under his belt in a bounce game this week.Neil added: “We’ve not had an easy run of it and it’s been tough to get a settled side out.“We had Glen Kamara and Ryan Inniss back from injury lay-offs on Saturday but it’s been problematic in terms of that.“I have been happy with the squad,  I can get them all fit it would be welcome but we’ve not been able to get that.”

title: something to be proud of majority back dundees new va
story: It has been branded by some as a waste of money and a blot on Dundee’s landscape.But it appears the majority of locals are happy with the city’s new £80 million V&ampA museum.An exclusive online poll by the Evening  has revealed more than 80% of our readers have either already paid a visit to the attraction or plan on doing so soon – about 40% each.Just 18% said they didn’t plan on visiting the V&ampA at all.A total of 444 people responded to our survey featuring a series of questions about people’s early perceptions of the museum of design.Nearly two-thirds of those who took part in the poll said they were happy with the public money that had been used to build and run the attraction.Respondent Stan Riley defended the spending, insisting the benefits “will be reaped many times over” by future generations.Paul McFadyen, from Menzieshill, added: “The money for the project was invested over a decade. I would actually say the museum is good value for money  anything.”Just 7% were “not fussed” about the spend while 32% said they would like to have seen the cash invested elsewhere.Reader Mark Petrie said he felt it would be years before the city knows for certain whether it was worth the money while Alison Donald wrote: “Meantime, what is happening to the people of Dundee using foodbanks?”We asked people to rate the V&ampA from one to 10, based on what they’d seen of the museum so far.A total of 179 people – 40% – gave it full marks, with another 11% giving it nine out of 10 and 10% rating it as eight out of 10.Tele reader Dave Alexander wrote: “I love it, for once we have something to be proud of in our city. Work in progress, I say.”Mike Swan added: “Heck of a lot better than what was there before. Don’t knock it, enjoy it.”Just 49 people, 11% of those who responded, said they’d give it one out of 10, with the other placings spread between 2%-6%.We asked readers to tell us what their favourite part of V&ampA Dundee was. The most popular was the museum’s appearance from the outside, which was top of the list for 170 people – 38% of respondents. 100vw, 620px" /Nearly 30% said the permanent exhibitions, including Charles Rennie Mackintosh’s iconic Oak Room, was their favourite part.A total of 58 people – 13% – voted for the temporary Ocean Liners exhibition while nine folk said the cafe or restaurant was their favourite. Just 79 people said they didn’t like any part.We also asked readers to identy the biggest benefit to Dundee of having the museum. More than 40% said they felt the indirect jobs the museum would bring to the city, through attracting investment from other companies, was the biggest pluspoint.Lisa Lawrence wrote: “It will give confidence to businesses looking to move to the city.“Growth has to start somewhere so why not with this investment in a great city?”A further 22% said they believed V&ampA Dundee had improved the way the city looked, though just 5% felt the biggest benefit would be educating people in design and the arts.A further 6% felt the jobs created by the museum itself was the biggest thing to celebrate.Just 18% of people said they felt the V&ampA would bring no benefits to Dundee.A sceptical Ian McGhee wrote: “In a couple of years one or two of those new hotels will be closed as there are too many of them, and the V&ampA will be used for local kids as a school trip. There won’t be demand for hotels long-term.”

title: we are not manchester city csaba explains why he feels being dundee united boss is the hardest job in scottish football
story: There were some cursory glances around the Press room at the Falkirk Stadium after Dundee United’s 2-0 win on Saturday when boss Csaba Laszlo, almost out of nowhere, asserted the following.“The most dficult job in the Scottish Championship, or Scottish football at the moment, is to be the manager of Dundee United.”He qualied that statement by adding that it is also dficult for his players to pull on the black and tangerine but his remarks did pique the interests of those gathered.It wasn’t so much disagreement or astonishment that filled the room but more a sense of being taken aback by the brutal honesty of a man who has been under such pressure of late.He eased some of the weight on his shoulders with the result at Falkirk under what were strange circumstances – namely going up against predecessor Ray McKinnon in the opposite dugout for a side sitting bottom and pointless.And it was clear that, despite assertions by some that Csaba is daft or clueless, he was very aware of the ramications had he not got the right result.“We showed good team spirit under pressure, they handled it positively,” Csaba commented as he laid out his case to the gathered press.“Now we can close this chapter and look ahead to the next game which will be very dficult.“This is the third season where the fans have been disappointed to be in the second tier and we are talking about a very massive, strong and passionate club that wants to be in Premiership.“If something doesn’t go right immediately you have noise which is OK but we don’t want to hide behind anything.“We have this pressure and we have to accept.“We don’t want to spend one more year in the Championship – it’s not good.“The Dundee United fans don’t want to hear that from the board, the manager or anybody. They want to have the target of promotion and winning the league.“This is pressure, this is normal but you have to understand we have a budget that isn’t any higher than other teams in the main.“You have to bring a team together. We had 19 players leave and 16 players come in for the new season.“We can’t click our fingers and have the team work fantastically.“There are rules at the club about how many or which kind of players we can bring in within our budget.“It is not easy, we are not Manchester City with an owner behind you who can give you £20 million to go and spend.“We have to work with the budget we have to get the best for the club.“The Dundee United board have done a fantastic job. It is not easy to convince players from abroad to come to the Scottish Championship with everything else around.”It was quite a defence – but probably one that was coming after weeks of trying to keep a lid on it following poor results against Alloa and Morton.Yes, he has not had his troubles to seek with injury and scrutiny from all angles but it seems to be just the beginning for Csaba in his most tough of jobs.In the next four weeks they take on title rivals Ross County, Ayr United, Partick Thistle and Inverness. They kick off that run at home to County on Saturday.“I don’t just look at one game being more important than the other because you can’t afford to take any game lightly,” Csaba added. “You have to take every opponent seriously, whether they be at the top, middle or bottom of the league.”

title: Blainie 9 defies the odds in charity race
story: &nbsp&nbspIn 2016, Blainie White  was diagnosed with a form of Batten disease which affects just eight people in the UK. It is a neurological condition which causes gradual loss of sight and movement, leaving the schoolgirl wheelchair-bound.The condition also causes Blainie to suffer from epilepsy.However, a team of dedicated family and friends have rallied round to raise money for specialist equipment which could transform her quality of le, and helped Blainie complete the Baxters River Ness 5KM race last Sunday.Her proud dad Scott  said: &ldquoThere was a full squad of us out doing the run and that was fantastic. It was really good for Blainie to be able to do it.&ldquoShe was really enjoying all the noise and the music. You would never have thought that she would be able to do it, but she did.&ldquoWe have raised nearly &pound700 just through doing the run, which is brilliant.The family are raising money for a flotation device which will allow Blainie to swim, as well as a robust wheelchair to help her enjoy the great outdoors.&ldquoShe just loves going in the pool, Mr White said.&ldquoHowever, it' between &pound700 and &pound800 for a device.&ldquoWe are also looking at getting another wheelchair as well because we need one that' a bit bigger for when she' outside school.&ldquoWe are always out doing walks which is another reason we need a more robust wheelchair for her.&ldquoGetting out and about in the fresh air is something she really enjoys, but it also helps with her condition because it tires her out.&ldquoSleep is so important because  she doesn&rsquot get enough, that heightens the seizures.Blainie' cause is also being championed by the Royal Bank of Scotland, where three relatives work.The bank' staff in Inverness have picked the Batten Disease Family Association as their chosen charity for next year.&ldquoRBS have taken BDFA on as their charity of the year which is absolutely fantastic, Mr White added.&ldquoMy partner Laura and her sister both work at the bank and her other sister is the manager so I just kept pestering them. Every year they have a charity they pick and for them to pick the BDFA is brilliant.&ldquoAny money RBS raised will be doubled by the bank as well which is a huge bonus for us We are really grateful.Mr White says his daughter continues to inspire the family on a daily basis.&ldquoShe can&rsquot walk or talk any more, but she is always laughing and giggling, he said.&ldquoShe does get a lot out of le. She' an inspiration to us all.- To donate to Blainie' fund, visit justgiving/crowdfunding/littlebeesbattleTuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Entrance to Victorian Market to get facelift
story: WORK&nbspcould begin on the Victorian Market' makeover as early as January.Highland Council has submitted planning applications to improve the appearance of the Academy Street entrance to the complex, which dates back to 1869.The plans involve bringing the glazed screen closer to the street in order to improve visibility into the market.The local authority says this will make the site more accessible, as well as improving security by reducing the number of access points on Academy Street to one.An uplighting system is also set to be installed in order to highlight the historic architecture of the building, and signage will be removed to &ldquo historic integrity to the Academy Street facade.The project marks the first stage of an action plan, which is being implemented by the council and the Inverness Common Good Fund, which is also set to build a business case for the remodelling of the market hall.No timescale for the completion of the work has yet been finalised, but an application for a grant of &pound30,250 has been submitted to the Inverness Townscape Heritage project.The news of the redevelopment came just days after traders in the Queensgate Arcade section of the market spoke of their struggle to deal with ongoing issues with the complex roof.Businesses in the privately-owned section of the building have been forced to take action to deal with repeated leaks which have at times forced them to close.Toni Rutherford, of the Little Teapot cafe, believes businesses in the market need help to deal with the problem.&ldquoIt is really frustrating for us that this problem keeps reappearing, she said.&ldquoIt' not good, especially when you walk into the arcade and see all the buckets.&ldquoIt' not a good impression for customers.&ldquoWe understand that there will be issues with the age of the building but that' all the more reason to take care of it, especially  people are wanting to make all these improvements to the building.&ldquoThree quarters of the building is owned by the council but the section we are in is privately owned.&ldquoThat means that any issues with the roof in our section have to be dealt with by us as traders.&ldquoThere have been times where we have had to close because of it. We have had waterfalls coming into the tearoom while customers have been in.&ldquoAlthough dferent sections of the building are owned by dferent people we are all under one roof, so we feel there should be some help available for the situation.&ldquoEveryone in the building needs to come together to get the problem solved.Tuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Gay pride march to go ahead
story: &nbspA gay pride march through the centre of Inverness has been given the go-ahead.Proud Ness, which will take place on October 6, has been at the centre of a bitter row after Donald Morrison, a home mission worker with the Free Church of Scotland , submitted a petition to Highland Council signed by 600 people opposing the event on "biblical, religious and moral grounds".In response, thousands of supporters signed counter petitions, saying gay pride was celebrated all over the world and the people of Inverness wanted to be on the right side of history.The council confirmed this morning the march can go ahead."We have notied the organisers that Highland Council and Police Scotland have no objections to the march being held as per the details in their notice of intention," the spokeswoman said.Previously, the spokeswoman said the petitions from both sides would not have a bearing on the decision process as the raised matters of concern were not sufficient reason to refuse the parade.Tuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Horror over plan for hundreds of trucks to pass Inverness school
story: &nbsp&nbspThe six-month operation, which is due to begin next spring, would take the lorries via Cloverfield Road, the southern distributor route, B8082 and onto the A9.Contractor, forestry management company Scottish Woodlands, has told Highland Council it has reached agreement with a neighbouring farmer for a track to be upgraded to give lorries access to the woods.But local community figures say that does not address the issue of public safety.The firm says the work at Balvonie Woods is essential.Inverness South councillor Ken Gowans said: &ldquoThis involves 480 truck journeys. To put that size of truck through a residential area, past Inshes Primary, is an unacceptable risk not to mention the disruption that could cause to the community. Some of the school community were horried at the prospect.Inverness South Community council secretary Bob Roberts said: &ldquoNo matter what they do the lorries will pose problems.&ldquoI&rsquom very concerned for the pupils&rsquo safety because as well as this, at certain times of day the parking around the school is horrendous.The community council is still to formulate its official response to Highland Council.Scottish Woodlands&rsquo regional development manager Bruce Taylor said: &ldquoIt' quite early days. There&rsquoll be a consultation period from now until the end of the year and we&rsquoll look at all options.&ldquo The point is to raise the proposal into the public arena and get responses with an expectation that we would be attending community council meetings to discuss the matter.&ldquoAt the end of the day, the wood is becoming unsafe because there is wind-throw in it and we need to find a solution to it because the owner is becoming concerned that at some point somebody might get hurt by a fallen tree.Dates are still to be arranged for consultation events.Tuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Just get on with it Eastgate Hostel owners told
story: &nbsp&nbspPat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, said the owners should &ldquostart now and stop making excuses after they said they were &ldquofocusing 100 per cent on moving forward with plans to finally tackle the eyesore.Owners Imtaiz Ali and a Mr Cheng recently said they hoped a contract for demolition could be in place before the end of November, but work may not start until after the festive period to avoid inconveniencing neighbouring traders.In answer to further questions posed to them by the Courier, through agent Gary Johnston of GH Johnston Building Consultants, they also revealed more about their plans for the shop spaces and two holiday apartments set to be created when the building is restored.&ldquoMr Cheng intends to reinstate his quality food takeaway restaurant, Mr Johnston said.&ldquoThe other shop unit will be available for rent as a class one shop, restaurant, hot food takeaway or other business considered suitable in the town centre. This may require a further planning application to Highland Council.&ldquoThe holiday apartments are aimed at visitors to Inverness and the Highlands and are commensurate with similar holiday lets in the High Street.&ldquoAs the apartments will be new and with a generous floor area, they will be at the higher end of the quality lets.They owners said they would take &ldquosoundings from Inverness Business Improvement District in terms of when would be the best time to start demolition work and refused to discuss why it had taken more than 2000 days to get anything done.Mr Johnston said: &ldquoThe owners will not make any comment on the past as they are now focusing 100 per cent on moving forward to get the scaffolding off the street and starting on the rebuild.But Mrs Hayden said she wanted to see action as soon as possible and there had been enough talk in the city about moving things forward.&ldquoStart now and don&rsquot use Christmas as an excuse. Get [the scaffolding] down. Today' a lovely day to start, she said.&ldquoWe&rsquove had enough excuses &ndash I&rsquom fed up of excuses.She said that when the fire happened her grand-daughter had been an infant, adding: &ldquoThat grand-daughter is about to be seven. That puts it in perspective &ndash it' been far too long.&ldquoAction is what is needed. Never mind consulting everybody &ndash everyone in that area wants rid of the scaffolding.&ldquoDon&rsquot wait until after Christmas because then the weather will be bad and then there&rsquoll be another excuse.Tuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Models needed for Inverness charity event
story: &nbsp&nbspThe event, to be held at Inverness Town House, is being organised by the Archie Foundation.It is looking for 10 males and 10 females aged over 14 and of all shapes and sizes with any connection to Raigmore' children' unit or the foundation.They could include former patients and their families, or staff.The new children' unit opened in 2016 following a &pound2 million appeal launched by the foundation in conjunction with The Inverness Courier.The foundation is now hoping to raise &pound160,000 for the Fresh Air project which will include fun features and topiary animals such as a 30ft Nessie.The fashion show will be held on Friday November 30 from 7pm to 10pm. It will be watched by about 100 people and include entertainment from TFX Performing Arts Academy.Jackie Cuddy, manager of the city' Eastgate Shopping Centre and a member of the foundation' Highland fundraising committee, said no experience was necessary.&ldquoWe are looking for people who have benefited from or been part of the work of this wonderful children' facility helping to provide first class care for the children of the Highlands and Islands, she said.&ldquoThis is a &lsquoreal&rsquo fashion show for all ages over 14 and all shapes and sizes.&ldquoIf there are families out there that have gone through a tough time recently, this experience could help to lt them and make them feel special. It also gives them the opportunity to give something back which is important to a lot of people.Models will have their hair and make-up professionally done by Gorgeous Hair Salon, Body Shop, Debenhams and Boots. Clothes will be provided by Eastgate retailers and independent retailer Rouge Boutique.Anyone wanting to take part, should email marketing@eastgate-centre with details about themselves and links to the unit or foundation.Tuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Pensioner pleads for help with poorly cat
story: &nbspAn Inverness pensioner is appealing for help with her cat' medical treatment after discovering that her monthly pet plan does not cover the cost of an X-ray.Marie MacIver' five-year-old cat Charlie has a painful leg and needs the scan to determine what treatment can be given.However, Mrs MacIver, who relies on disability benefit, is unable to afford the X-ray, which will cost about &pound300.She has now contacted the&nbspmedia in a plea for kind-hearted Invernessians to come forward."There is no way I can afford to pay for the X-ray," she said."Since it' very dficult for me to get out, I have already had to pay for the vet to come to the house and give Charlie a medical, as well as a bottle of anti-inflammatories which cost &pound29 and did nothing."I already pay &pound10 a month for a pet plan but it doesn&rsquot seem to cover anything."I have tried everywhere to get help with the vet' bills &ndash the PDSA, RSPCA and Cats Protection, but I haven&rsquot been able to get help from anywhere."I hate to see him in pain and I think it' getting worse."It came out of the blue about a month ago, and now it is just not going away."Mrs MacIver lives alone with Charlie and says she has a special bond with her little cat."He' my companion and is often the only company I have," she said."He sleeps on my bed and follows me into the kitchen, and he seems to know not to stray too far from the house because I need him."He' really more like a dog than a cat."I try my best to take care of him but things like this are very dficult, and it is such a shame because he is a lovely little cat."I need to help Charlie get better."&nbspCan you help Mrs MacIver with the cost of Charlie' X-ray? Email us via newsdesk@spp-groupTuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote &ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past 15 years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived &ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in 2016-17 by &pound31.1 million. As of last weekend, it was valued at &pound2,013,164,722.61.Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: &ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhaps  it' invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, it' not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The council' investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobacco  and China' second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The council' finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.&ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.&ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.&ldquoYou might take a view&hellip would you invest in banks, for example? They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.&ldquoIt' a dficult balancing act but it' certainly within your rights  you wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.&ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund &ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that &ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: &ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.&ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk and  in the usual way.Tuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Response to Charlie tale stuns cat owner
story: &nbsp&nbspMarie MacIver, who lives in Hilton and relies on disability benefit, lives alone with her five-year-old cat Charlie.She got in touch with the Courier after it became apparent that Charlie' injured leg needed an X-ray, which she could not afford.She had already contacted animal welfare charities without success.After we printed the story last week, we were inundated with offers of help for little Charlie &ndash and Mrs MacIver admitted she was moved to tears.&ldquoI don&rsquot know what I would have done without everyone who offered to help, she said.&ldquoI&rsquove been in tears because people have been so nice. I had a card from a lady wishing me and Charlie all the best. That was such a touching thing for someone to do.&ldquoThe card has pride of place on my mantelpiece.&ldquoPeople are just so kind, even to a poor little animal like Charlie.&ldquoSome people would see him as just a cat but to me he is much more than that.&ldquoI just want to say thank you so much to everyone who has been in touch wanting to help. I didn&rsquot think anything would come of it.Local cat owner Ian Aird came to Mrs MacIver' aid, donating enough money to cover the cost of the X-ray, leaving her gobsmacked.&ldquoI can&rsquot thank Ian enough, she said.&ldquoIt was so kind of him to do that for me and Charlie.&ldquoI&rsquom so incredibly grateful to Ian. I have no words that can describe how grateful I am for what he has done.Mr Aird said: &ldquoI am a cat owner myself and when I read the story I felt so much sympathy for Mrs MacIver.&ldquoShe is an elderly lady and she doesn&rsquot get out of the house very much so that' why I thought it was important that I helped her.&ldquoFor someone in her position, Charlie is often her only companion.&ldquoThis situation seems to have resonated with a lot of people, particularly cat owners around Inverness.Charlie has now been diagnosed with patellar dysplasia, where the kneecap is slightly misshapen, and requires no further treatment other than keeping weight off his leg.&ldquoI&rsquom so relieved it' nothing serious, Mrs MacIver added.&ldquoBut I have taken out an insurance plan, and I would encourage everyone else to do the same in case something like this happens again.Tuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Star honour for city cadet
story: &nbsp&nbspEuan Stewart from 1st Battalion the Highlanders&rsquo Inverness detachment has been appointed the battalion' new Cadet Regimental Sergeant Major .The 17-year-old who joined the youth organisation five years ago is being championed for his long list of achievements.Graeme Wells from the army cadet force said the high flying cadet has climbed right up the ranks to completed his Master Cadet, which is the highest a cadet can reach.On top of his cadet achievements he has also had the honour of being the Lord Lieutenant' Cadet of Inverness-shire.This position allowed him to assist the Lord Lieutenant of Inverness-shire, Donald Cameron of Lochiel, in his duties as Her Majesty The Queen' appointed representative for the area.Mr Wells said Mr Stewart was also an &ldquoexcellent shooter who has represented the battalion on several occasions in regional and national shooting competitions, including the Inter-Service Cadet Rle meeting at Bisley Ranges in Surrey.Last year he scooped the battalion its first trophy in this contest, coming in first in the Patriotic 500 competition.Mr Wells added: &ldquoEuan was promoted to his new position at Fort George last Saturday while taking part in training for the upcoming Scottish Cadet Military Skills Competition in which he has been named as the team' Section Commander.Mr Stewart, who is a Culloden Academy pupil and has his heart set on studying mechanical engineering at university, said he was delighted with the honour.He said: &ldquoMy brother Andrew was originally in the cadets and he achieved a high level so that inspired me and we also have connections with the Honorary Colonel Councillor Carolyn Caddick whose son was the last RSM so and I guess I was quite inspired by him too.Tuesday 2 Oct 2018 3:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: scotland squad
story: Aberdeen&#8217s Scott McKenna and Graeme Shinnie have been named in Alex McLeish&#8217s Scotland squad.The Reds duo are in the group of 23 selected to face Israel in Haa on Thursday, October 11 in the Nations League Group C1 fixture and Portugal in a friendly at Hampden three days later.Defender McKenna, who has four caps, s to the squad after missing the last two internationals against Belgium and Albania through injury. The 21-year-old captained the Dark Blues against Mexico in June during the summer tour of Central and South America.Meanwhile Pittodrie captain Shinnie, who has two caps, keeps his place in Gothenburg Great McLeish&#8217s squad after featuring as a sub in last month&#8217s friendly against Belgium.Dons&#8217 winger Gary Mackay-Steven misses out on selection, despite a strong start to the season.Former Aberdeen winger Ryan Fraser, now with English Premier League Bournemouth, has also been named in the squad.

title: sign our petition to change time of aberdeen semi final clash at hampden4
story: Dons fans have branded the decision to make Aberdeen’s League Cup semi-final against Rangers at Hampden a noon kick-off “an absolute disgrace”.Supporters’ groups, the club and Hearts have all hit out after it was revealed both semi-finals would be played at the national stadium in Glasgow on the same day.And now the Evening Express has launched a petition in an effort to make the SPFL reconsider the ridiculous scheduling of the Aberdeen v Rangers League Cup semi-final on Sunday October 28.The lunchtime kick-off is an outrageous time for fans from the north-east to get to Hampden – and scheduling the Hearts v Celtic semi on the same day at the same venue only compounds the problem.Sign this petition to send a message to the SPFL that’s loud and clear: This showpiece fixture MUST be changed to a new venue or time for the sake of the fans.

title: aberdeen out of school club praised by inspectors
story: An Aberdeen out of school club has been lavished with praise in a recent report.Great Western OOSC @ Holburn West was given the highest possible mark following an unannounced inspection.The Care Inspectorate awarded the club excellent in the quality of care and support and the quality of management and leadership.One parent told inspectors their children are “very happy there, therefore we in turn are happy with their care”.Inspectors last reviewed the city centre club in 2015, where it was awarded two good and two very good grades.The report said: “We saw her display excellent leadership skills and role modelling throughout the inspection.“Any concerns raised by parents or incidents that arose at the club were fully explored with a clear focus on supporting the best possible outcomes for the children and working in partnership with parents.”

title: survey 99 on board for skate park
story: Nearly 100% of respondents to a study have thrown their weight behind skate park plans.As part of a feasibility study, 99% of people said they would be happy for the skate park to be built in Banchory.The group behind the plans was given the green light in May to seek a lease for the land at Bellfield Park by the Marr Area Committee.Due to the nature of the land, Banchory Skatepark Group  would need to gain a lease from a sherf before starting to build.BSG was tasked with producing a feasibility study as part of the application to the sherf.Russ Crichton, chairman of the BSG, said: “The feasibility study covered many areas but of particular interest was the community consultation.“The consultation threw up a fantastic result and very supportive comments.“Overall there were 531 responses with 99.3% support to a new skate park in Banchory.“We are now completing the specication to issue out to Public Contracts Scotland to gather bids for the new skate park.“We are also continuing to develop the design and preparation for our planning application which will take place in the next few weeks.”The consultation asked respondents 17 questions about the skate park, covering topics from the local need for the development to the possibility of a fee being charged for use.If the fee were to be introduced, the report says, it may only be applicable at night, and will primarily be used to fund a “pay as you go” floodlight system.Respondents decided £3 per hour was a fair price to charge for the lighting.Almost three-quarters  of respondents said that floodlighting should be part of the facility.The cost of the project is estimated at £240,000, 25% of which will be matched by the Banchory Developers Fund.

title: work on revamp of aberdeens union terrace gardens may not start this year1
story: Tenders to redevelop Union Terrace Gardens will close in the middle of this month, it has been revealed.Aberdeen City Council has still to appoint a contractor for the multi-million-pound revamp of the Victorian gardens and is accepting bids to carry out the work until later in the month.Douglas Lumsden, co-leader of the local authority, has not been able to give assurances the work – due to be completed in 2020 – will kick off this year, but has said it “hopes” to appoint a contractor by the end of the year.SNP group leader Stephen Flynn has raised concerns over perceived delays to the work.He said: “We’re all well aware that Union Terrace Gardens is behind schedule and the key thing at this stage is the administration ensure their revised timetable is kept to.“We can’t afford any further slippage.&#8221Construction has yet to start, but without a spade yet hitting the ground it is feared it may be impossible for the ambitious project to be completed within the estimated 18- to 24-month timeframe.Mr Lumsden said: “We’ve made it clear that we’re in the tender process just now and it’s just typical of the opposition trying to talk the city down when they should be getting behind the projects we’re putting in place.”A number of high-profile council projects have been delayed in recent years, including revamps of Broad Street, the art gallery, Provost Skene’s House and the Central Library.London Olympic Park architects LDA Design won planning permission for its Union Terrace Gardens plan in March.The proposals include new walkways, an amphitheatre and a cafe.They aim to conserve the Victorian park’s heritage and to “sustain Aberdeen’s performance in times of economic dficulty”, according to a design statement.Other features of the scheme include a new accessible walkway route into the gardens from Union Street.Lt access from Union Street into the upper level of the gardens will also be provided through a new entrance building on Union Terrace at the existing Burns Monument.The central lawn space would be retained as a flexible space for large-scale gatherings and events and there would be a new entrance opposite His Majesty’s Theatre.The plans mark the latest development in the future of the city park. Councillors rejected proposals for a £140 million transformation of the gardens in 2012.Businessman Sir Ian Wood had offered £50m towards the cost and earlier this year claimed it was a “tragedy” Aberdeen City Council decided to reject his multi-million-pound plan for the renovation of the gardens.

title: gap should be broader to win two in borders
story: Aberdeen Grammar came within two minutes of a Border double at Selkirk, only to have the game cruelly snatched away from them.Home flanker Sean Nixon crashed over the Rubislaw outfit’s line to tie up the scores at 26 points apiece.Worse was to come for the visitors when winger Frazer Anderson slotted the touchline conversion, making it a perfect day for the player who kicked all of his four attempts at goal in the last-gasp 28-26 win.Grammar head coach Ali O’Connor was understandably gutted at the conclusion of a game his side had controlled for most of the 80 minutes.They went into the last quarter leading 26-7 on the back of four tries, scored by stand-off Sam Knudson, flanker Alex Dravitski, scrum-half Cairan Wood and winger Nat Coe.O’Connor said: “It was hard to take, particularly as we had the lion’s share of the game, and dominated up front.“Normally I would be happy to have taken seven points of a possible 10 against two Border sides, including Kelso last week.“But we must learn to close out games, and not be too flamboyant going into the closing stages of a game we have seemingly won.“There were, however, some outstanding performances, including first-rate showings from Ewan Stewart, Chris Jollands and captain Sam Knudson.”Playing into a stf first-half breeze, Grammar did not make the best of the conditions, only taking a 12-7 lead into the break.But early in the second half two well-taken tries, both converted by Knudson, saw them apparently on their way.But the Borderers had other ideas, battling back with touchdowns of their own to snatch an unlikely victory.In Glasgow, Gordonians kept up their unbeaten run, easing past Hillhead Jordanhill 25-17 to the satisfaction of head coach Ryan Morrice.He said: “This is the kind of game we would have lost last season, but we have learned how to keep our composure and stick to the game plan.“The win has set us up nicely for a tilt at leaders Newton Stewart at Countesswells. The try bonus point was very welcome. We are in a good place.”The Gordonians tries were scored by Matt Hillier, Danny Usugo, David Ilyine and Chris Simpson. Full-back Graeme Crawford kicked a conversion and a penalty.At the Meadows, newly-promoted Ellon ran out convincing 36-16 winners against derby rivals Aberdeen Wanderers, earning them bragging rights in the Caley Division 1 clash.Head coach Craig Parslow said: “We have a great team ethic, everyone is playing for each other.”

title: letters to the editor week 34
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 26/08/18, 9:00 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Sir,The decision of Argyll and Bute Council to allow expansion of Poll na Gille and BDNC Loch Shuna is reprehensible.These sites have been named as being the first and third worst respectively of all the salmon farms in Scotland on an index of welfare and health measures, including premature death rates, sea lice numbers, escapes, breaches of biomass limits and seal shooting .Despite the above, there was a decision made by Argyll and Bute planning department that Environmental Impact Assessments were not required for the expansion of either of these fish farms.The Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform committee report on the environmental impacts of salmon farming stated, in a letter dated March 5, 2018, to the Rural Economy and Connectivity committee that: &#8216The committee is supportive of aquaculture, but further development and expansion must be on the basis of a precautionary approach and must be based on resolving the environmental problems.  The status quo is not an option.&#8217It is apparent that Argyll and Bute Council does not intend to adopt the precautionary approach recommended, but continues to agree to unsustainable expansion, even at locations which are in breach of the current standards required.Christine Richards, Friends of the Sound of JuraSir,We would like to invite your more adventurous readers to join us on our Lake District challenge next spring and help save lives and rebuild futures shattered by meningitis.They will conquer eight peaks, all above 3,000 feet, over two days. It will require energy, commitment and a positive attitude, but will reward those taking part with breath-taking views, wrapped up in a serious adventure and a weekend they’ll never forget – there’s a great team spirit amongst those taking part and many come away from the challenge having made lelong friends.Every step they take will also help us to fight meningitis and move us closer to our vision of a future where no one in the UK dies from this devastating disease and everyone affected gets the support they need.Registration is just £49, with a fundraising pledge of £500. Accommodation, food, travel and the support of a qualied and experienced mountain leader and safety team are all included, and I&#8217ll be there to support you throughout your fundraising journey. It takes place between Thursday May 2 and Sunday May 5 next year.Find out more at www.MeningitisNow.org or by emailing me at michaelai@meningitisnow.org .Michaela Ifill, Meningitis NowSir,The World&#8217s Biggest Coffee Morning event is fast approaching and we would love for readers in Argyll and Bute to get involved.Having become a national institution since it launched in 1990, it has raised millions to help change the lives of people living with cancer, including here in Argyll and Bute.Last year some 200,000 people said that they were planning on taking part in homes, workplaces and schools across the country &#8211 but the idea remains as simple as ever: come together as a community in support of people living with cancer and raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support.Cancer can affect every aspect of a person’s le, from their day-to-day living and relationships to their finances and mental health. Macmillan is there to help people with cancer live le as fully as they can.Offering a broad range of cancer information and support services &#8211 including a free support line and a community of over 7,700 healthcare professionals &#8211 demand for Macmillan’s services is constantly growing, but we rely on the generosity of the public to provide this support.Macmillan’s Coffee Morning takes place on Friday September 28 &#8211 but people can host whenever they want. Whoever they invite and whatever they serve, people are highly encouraged to host a Macmillan Coffee Morning in a way that suits them.If people can’t bake, that doesn’t have to stop them. Throughout September, headline partner M&ampS will be selling a selection of limited edition coffee morning products &#8211 including lots of cakes, biscuits and two exclusive mugs &#8211 with 10 per cent of proceeds going to Macmillan.Homes, workplaces and communities from the Shetland Islands to Land’s End will be hosting coffee mornings this year readers in Argyll and Bute can find events nearby using the interactive map on the Coffee Morning website www.macmillan.org.uk/coffee.Thank you to everyone who gets involved.Joanna Lumley, actress and Macmillan supporterSir,The SNP announced it is starting up a new &#8216fact-checking&#8217 service to monitor the accuracy of research and political statements.Many people in Scotland will be wondering  the SNP will be fact-checking the cost of its new independence blueprint. Analysis has continually shown that an independent Scotland would mean cuts to public spending and increased taxes.The SNP now has to answer serious questions about the real cost of independence as the latest GERS figures will once again show how much we benefit from being part of the UK. It&#8217s time for the separatists to be honest and accept the facts.With Labour embroiled in a new scandal almost every second day and the LibDems disappearing into irrelevance it&#8217s clear that only Ruth Davidson&#8217s Scottish Conservatives can stand up to Nicola Sturgeon&#8217s IndyRef2 obsession.Cllr Alastair Redman, Isle of Islay&nbsp

title: science matters week 36
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 09/09/18, 9:01 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.The multi-million dollar international trade in exotic pets has long been a bugbear of mine.Not only does it promote wild animals as  fashion accessories, but it also allows potentially dangerous microbes to jump to, and cause epidemics in, other species including humans. What’s more, even  they don’t mutate as occurred in the case outlined here,  released into the wild either by design or mistake these foreigners can cause havoc to local ecosystems.In a letter to the scientic journal Nature in 2003, a group of German scientists began ‘it has been rumoured that an unidentied crayfish…of marbled appearance and uncertain geographical origin that was introduced into the German aquarium trade in the mid 1990s, is capable of unisexual reproduction ’.The authors ended by warning that: ‘This crayfish…could become a menace to European freshwater systems, as the release of even one specimen into the wild would be enough to found a population that might out-compete native crayfish’.Now, 23 years later, this all-female crayfish has escaped into the wild.  Identied as a descendent of the fresh water slough crayfish from Florida, it is now called the marbled crayfish or Marmokrebs. So far it has invaded the waterways of at least nine European countries as well as Japan and Madagascar. Unravelling its origin reveals that a unique macro-mutation must have occurred in a single slough crayfish egg probably caused by heat or cold shock whilst in transit from Florida to Germany for the pet market.The resulting female hatchling possessed three sets of chromosomes per cell  and the ability to produce clones of itself without a mate and at very high frequency.Because of its warm climate and abundant freshwater habitats, Madagascar has seen the most rapid colonisation with Marmokrebs. Millions of the animals have invaded the countries lakes, rice paddies and swamps and are threatening its seven endemic crayfish species.It is only a matter of time before this scenario is repeated in other locations, destroying valuable ecosystems and eliminating indigenous species.

title: some close shaves in the strc
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated: 10/09/18, 9:00 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to ?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Subscribe NowThere were only two Mid Argyll crews competing in the Scottish Tarmac Rally Championship  Pendragon stages at Warcop training camp in Cumbria on Sunday August 26.They were Donald Bowness and navigator Paul Gribben in their Vauxhall Nova and Jamie Miller and Ian McCulloch in their Citroen C2R2Max.
